book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: All good things must come to an end. It is hard to forget where I was when Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows was released and I read the epic conclusion to the heptology. My daughter turns thirteen this week, the same as this book, and a friend who worked at the library saved me a copy, the first from the library to read it. With two kids under two, I still managed to read the entire book in under thirty six hours in between naps, baths, and meal times. Harry’s tale was complete, and I moved on with my life, rereading the series time after time after time as I navigated motherhood with four kids in five years. The kids got older, old enough to read and reread Harry on their own as I moved toward more literary fiction and nonfiction tomes. As the kids moved closer to that magic age eleven, I began to view the series as a kids series and no longer read it every time I needed a tonic to pep up my life. While I engaged with the kids in the same questions that me and my friends have asked for years, I did not necessarily partake in reading Harry with them as I let the kids savor the books for themselves. Adults in the real muggle world lead busy lives, busier than even that of Harry and his friends, making time that we do have precious, and the idea of rereading a book may not have the same appeal as it did when we had our entire lives in front of us. Reading is supposed to be pleasureful, something J.K. Rowling taught us from the moment Hagrid knocked down the door to the hut at sea and told Harry that he was a wizard. Late last year I proposed to a group of women that we reread Harry in 2020. There is never enough time to savor the series as we should but each of us could take as long as we needed to read through Harry’s magical world once again. Then in March, time seemed to have stopped and like the time turner allowed us to have extra time to read as we stayed home and navigated a real world crisis. Many things are wrong or sad about the year 2020, but making the decision to reenter the wizarding world of Harry Potter is looking, in Ron’s words, bloody brilliant. Like he has countless other times, Harry Potter and his fictional world and fight against evil has been with me in 2020, a time when I desperately needed some magic in my life. I had timed my own reread to finish on Harry and J.K. Rowling’s birthday July 31, but like I did way back in 2007, I could not resist and finished in a little over a day of reading. Harry indeed saved the day again. J.K. Rowling has noted many times that Harry Potter is about death and how the living have taken to heart. She did not lead the happiest childhood, and Harry has been her way of coping and grieving. In the each of the first six books a key character or magical creature dies, leaving the living to deal with the consequences surrounding the death and how to move on with their lives. No where was this more clear than at the end of the fifth book where Harry grappled with Sirius’ demise and reviewed the prophecy with Dumbledore multiple times. Dumbledore buffeted Harry’s mood by noting that even if there was no prophecy, would he not want to honor the memories of his parents and loved ones by continuing the fight against Voldemort and the Death Eaters. The answer is a clear yes, that Harry by age fifteen has friends worth fighting for and he would do all in his power to defeat Voldemort once and for all. The seventh book does indeed have a war and lots of death, some more painful to read about than others. Yet, the seventh book also brings together all the peripheral characters, places, spells, and creatures who comprised the first six books in an epic conclusion. It may be about death, but the Deathly Hallows is Harry’s quest toward coronation as the Boy Who Lived, a tale compelling enough that even a mother of four adolescent and teenaged kids can read it in a little over a day. While the final two hundred pages are action packed, Rowling begins the tale with a parting of ways and later a wedding. We find out that Dudley actually had fond feelings for Harry, and later through interviews, find out that Rowling went back and forth as to whether Dudley should have a magical child. She ultimately decided against it, but I believe the idea of Dudley fathering a magical child is what this series is all about- teaching children and older readers that all creatures should be viewed as equals, that it is does not matter if one comes from a muggle, half blood, or pure blood parentage, and that it is not abilities that make a person who they are but their actions toward their fellow humanity. With all the fan fiction in the world, it would be intriguing if Dudley ever did have a magical child and what the consequences would be for his family. Yet, in book seven, as we are about to enter the grand climax, the treatment of muggle born witches and wizards and elf’s and goblins and all those deemed inferior are the stark difference between Harry and Voldemort, how they view their fellow creatures and the consequences of these actions. That Harry and Voldemort came from similar backgrounds is not to be overlooked either, as it becomes clear that Harry exhibits, in Dumbledore’s words, one in a million, empathy, whereas the former Tom Riddle does not possess a bit of remorse. As such, the long battle over souls and control of the magical universe begins. No one said that the journey would be easy. Ron even noted that it wasn’t like they were going to find one Horcrux a day. That would have been too easy. The friendship of Harry, Ron, and Hermoine is tested to the limits, but as is this series is at heart for kids, Rowling would never allow the trio to separate; that would be too painful to take. Dumbledore knew each of their strengths, leaving each the tools they would need to ultimately complete the quest. They penetrate the outer reaches of magic, something farthest from the minds of most other seventeen year olds with their whole lives ahead of them. They are prepared to die if it means creating a world where all creatures are free to live freely. Whereas on the surface, Harry Potter is a series for middle grade and young adult readers, this ultimate book contains mature thinking topics that I wonder if the series should be read again when the teenaged reader is nineteen years older and can appreciate the scope of its depth. Rowling studied Lord of the Rings, Shakespeare, Arthurian legends, and other classic tales to develop the names and themes for her novels. In one small segment I noticed a passage that could have been borrowed from Lord of the Rings and another that could have been borrowed from Return of the Jedi. That J.K. Rowling takes ideas from each of these tales and weaves a more complex one of her own speaks to the brilliance of her as a writer and Harry as an epic hero. As the book and series come to a close, Harry is indeed the one in a million man that Dumbledore envisioned him to be, the one who could bring down the dark arts once and for all. Harry defeating Voldemort has become more emotional for me with each passing reading. We know nineteen years later that Harry marries Ginny and Ron marries Hermoine and all of them lead relatively normal adult lives. In the defining moment, where evil is defeated once and for all and families faced with uncertain futures are reunited, one can not help but shed tears of joy, especially in the uncertain times we are living in now. What makes this magical series appropriate for adults with busy lives is the end, where Harry, Ginny, Ron, and Hermoine along with their school friends see their kids off to the Hogwarts Express. The adults turn wistful and giddy for their time spent at school, giving them cause to pause from their busy lives and perhaps reenter Hogwarts for a day or two to relive the magical memories of their youth. While there has not been much cause for celebration in 2020, reentering Harry Potter’s wizarding world has been the most joyous times for me this year. J.K. Rowling has created a series for the ages, one where the reader can slow down time and relive the magic again and again while creating new memories with their families over the years. Even though the series may be about death, in 2020, Harry Potter has been about the magic of life that I needed so desperately to help me through this unprecedented year. After all this time, ✨5+ magical ✨ 🧙‍♀️🔮🧙‍♂️

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: Thank you JK, for giving me a home away from home.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: Aaaaand it's over. Again.And I'm utterly shattered, but I'm also in a state of ecstasy because of how the many pieces of the puzzle the Harry Potter series is fitted. Seriously, I can't think of no other series of book so cautiously planned, in which all the details are important and everything - everything - makes sense in the way this does in the end.It was about time I truly appreciated what a fantastic world J.K. Rowling created with this series. As I had said before, I didn't really love this series before this reread - I simply liked it, and that was enough for me to not get the fweels and not to be in pain because of all the deaths that happened.Deaths which, by the way, made the book better and worse at the same time. Worse because duh, characters we learned to love no longer were; and better... because well, doesn't that prove how brave an author Rowling is? She doesn't go the safe, sugar-coated way. She goes in the painful and realistic one, even though this was not supposed to be a book for adults.This book is not my favourite in the series (that place goes for both The Goblet of Fire and The Prisoner of Azkaban), but it's still brilliant. The plot gets more complex than before, it's more action-packed and intense, and all the loose strings in the series finally get attached, that is to say, the missing explanations are given and the last twists delivered, some of which include this:Oh, Snape. A complex character, that one was. I never hated him. I admit sometimes I loathed him when he was unfair towards his students, but it was passing anger and I got over it; besides, he was a damn genius in Potion-making and magic in general. Now after reading book 7, I realised I actually feel kind of bad for him. All the life he didn't have... and all because he wallowed in his past.I'm eternally grateful for my decision of rereading this series. During it, I infected my brothers with HP obsession love, and I finally became one of those people who see the world of HP as real as our Muggle world, because as Albus Dumbledore said,Of course it is happening inside your head, Harry, but why on earth should that mean that it is not real?It'd be a lie if I say I'll never get over this series - I've gotten over worse things (i.e. The Monstrumologist) - but nonetheless I'll never forget about this journey, and of course, I'll always keep it in my heart, no matter how cheesy and unlike me that sounds.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: Truly the book which gets to me every time I reread it. Of course this also gets 5*s becuase I adore this entire series and there's no reason not to give out 5*s to an entire series. On the reread this one had me crying and babbling in happiness and sadness alike many times. I truly think that the power of love and friendship shine throughout this whole book and I just found it moving and magical. I don't need to go into much detail other than to say I love this series ending, even with all the sadness, and this book is magnificent.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: "After all this time?""Always," said Snape.”And, just like that, it's all over. I'll never forget this book for the emotions it manages to exude in each and every scene. I'll never forgive it for that, either. Hogwarts features far less here, than in the previous six books, which only makes our final return to it feel all the more poignant. The wonderful ending, and the tears I shed over it, served to encapsulate what this entire series promotes and what makes it so eternally powerful and beloved. Here, Rowling unites her readers, her characters, her army of dreamers and believers. Together we stand and together we fight against darkness. And that is why, after all this time, #always.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: POSSIBLE SPOILERSRating:After all this book has put me through and has been dragged through itself, it deserves a 5 star rating. Especially since it is the conclusion to such a beautiful series.Plot:My Blurb:Harry Potter, The Boy Who Lived, The Chosen One, is supposed to be in his last year at Hogwarts, enjoying the time with his best friends Ron Weasley and Hermione Granger.Instead, he has been forced to grow up fast, suffering through death, hardships, and even duels.Still stricken by the death of one of the most important people in his life, Harry sets off with Ron and Hermione to find the remaining Horcruxes that will destroy Lord Voldemort.The task proves a daunting one, but with the help of his friends, and some unknown people, he may be able to succeed.If he does, he may finally be able to put an end to the evil in his world, creating a better place for all.My Commentary:This book.This. Book.It killed me.Harry and his friends have to go through a lot of crap in this book. The bias, the society, the prejudice.Harry has to hide his face everywhere he goes, even at Bill and Fleur's wedding. Almost everyone is against him, and those who we think are with him, well, some of them end up betraying the trust. Some of them are people we would never expect that from. And then there are the people who we thought for sure were against Harry but end up being on his side.I can't even express how much this book infuriated, overjoyed, excited, scared, and everything me.Characters:Harry Potter:Harry is still pretty perfect. He forgives Dumbledore, he forgives Snape, he forgives Ron, he tries to save Peter Pettigrew, he saves Draco and his cronies, he even gives Voldemort a chance. I mean, seriously, this guy? Amazing.Harry knows what it takes to save everyone; he knows very well that this could end in his death. But he is willing to sacrifice that if it means keeping everyone else safe.For that, I admire him as a character and as a person. His development throughout this series is incredible and the changes he brings to the Wizarding world are even greater.Ron Weasley:Ron has to once again deal with the pressure of being The Boy Who Lived's best friend. He has to fight his feelings for one of his best friends since he does not want to hurt his other friend. He is struggling still to find his own destiny without being shadowed by Harry Potter's. He's not really sure where he fits into all the plans until he finds it himself.Hermione Granger:Hermione. God, Hermione. She is so fierce, so strong, so passionate. She changes her parents' memories to be like she never existed. If that's not a savage move right there, I don't know what is. She sticks with Harry even when Ron gives up on him, and she does not waver from the quest. She knows what they need to do and she is not ready to surrender.Ginny Weasley:I love this girl. She is not afraid to kick butt or to show that she can. She will defend herself and the people she loves until she can't anymore. She is so much like Harry; they are the perfect match.She, Luna, and Neville, along with a ton of other Hogwarts students, kept the D.A. running so that they could support Harry from afar. That is just so great. I love Ginny.Luna Lovegood:Luna Lovegood? Oh! You mean my favorite character EVER? That Luna Lovegood?She is eccentric and odd, but with that brings her uniqueness and strength. She is her own person completely and does not hesitate to express herself. Even when held captive, Luna does not waver but spends her time trying to find a way to escape with the others. Harry admires her so, Ron thinks she is just the greatest thing, and Hermione is one of her best friends. Luna's personality is so great, and I wish I had someone like her in my life.Neville Longbottom:Neville, the awkward, clumsy, dim Neville Longbottom, has transformed into a hero. He helped Harry defeat Voldemort. Not in a small, cheesy way, but in a HUGE, nessecary way. He was scared and impressionable, but he helped the D.A. and the journey to defeating Voldemort in an incredible way.I just love this chubby, awkward kid. And I love Matthew Lewis in the movies but for reasons other than his personality. . . .Draco Malfoy:He is just one of those villains I can't bring myself to hate. His personality was terrible, yes, but beneath all of that, he was a vulnerable boy whose choices were fogged by his parents. He did not get to choose who he was. His entire life, he spent it shadowed in the legacy of his father, Lucius Malfoy, the Death Eater.He was not evil. He wasn't really a villain.He was the son who never got a choice. He was a young man who needed a second chance. He was a student, like all others, who needed to learn. He was just a boy who needed saving, even if he didn't want to admit it.Plus I ship Dramione, so there's that.Fred Weasley:*sniff**stifles sobs*George Weasley:I cannot express my love for these twins. My sympathy for George is immeasurable. For the whole family it is.I don't think George is ever ok after what happens in the Battle of Hogwarts. I don't think he ever healed wholly, but I do believe that his family helped him. He found a wife, I know, and they had 2 kids. Roxanne and Fred.Of course, there was Fred. Of course he cried, he hurt, he yelled. Of course his children wondered why their dad cried and why their mum had to comfort him. Fred wanted to know whose memeories it was that made his dad smile. George told his kids stories, I'm sure. They know who Uncle Fred is, even if they won't meet him.I hope George got better. I really do.Bill and Fleur Weasley:Geez, The Golden Trio owes Bill and Fleur their lives. He kept them safe when they barely escaped from death. They healed Hermione after she was tortured. They . . . gave up the spot in their yard . . . I can't . . .Percy Weasley:I had honestly forgotten about Percy until he showed up again. In the beginning books, I liked him, then I hated him, and now I love him. He's still not a huge character, but he is sorry, and he has a heart, which is what matters.Molly Weasley:This lady. She accepted Harry as her own even when her family was already so big. She would do anything for her family. She was devestated when she lost one, she was fierce when she fought for one, and she loved when she saw all of them.She was ready to sacrifice herself for her children and she used the only mildly violent curse word in the whole series for herself. Of course, there were Ron's frequent outbursts, but really, Molly gets the fame.She took on Bellatrix for her daughter. And! And! She defeated her!Molly Weasley, everyone.Arthur Weasley:His excitement with the Muggle world is great. He has such a curious mind that wants to explore everything. This is usually something reserved for a child, but Arthur has it too.Remus Lupin:The last Marauder standing. I guess a group that tight knit must all have similar destinies.He is such an amazing guy. All around. Sure there were times where I was annoyed with him because he didn't appreciate Tonks, or he was going to leave his son, or he was going to sacrifice everything, but in the end, I cried for him.When he asked Harry to be the godfather for his son, I was so touched. I had so many feelings combined into one ball of emotion, and I'll admit that I teared up.He would be such a wonderful dad, no matter what he thought.He may have denied his love for Tonks, but it did show in this book. It was a messy, complicated relationship, but beautiful nonetheless.Nymphadora Tonks:Tonks is supportive, protective, and determined. Her first thought in the battle was of her husband's safety, and their journeys finished together. They brought a new life into the world, and yes, their son may be confused as to why his mum and dad left him, but he will be loved. He will have Andromeda, Harry, Hermione, Ron, Ginny, the kids, everyone.Anyway, this is about Tonks, not Teddy. She is hilarious too. Her hair and her features and "Don't call me Nymphadora."Oh, Tonks . . .Severus Snape:Snape, Snape, Severus Snape.So . . . Some of you are going to hate me for saying this but . . .I still don't really like him.*winces* Is it over?I know, I know! His story, Lily, jealousy! Yes, it's all very heartbreaking, and I like him a lot more than I used to, but I still don't really like him.All those years, he was terrible to Harry. Maybe it was to protect him, because he reminded Snape of the Potters. I don't deny that, but at the same time, just because Snape loved Lily, I can't forgive him for all he has done.Snape was Neville's boggart. His biggest fear.Harry was not scared of Snape as Neville was, no, but he was intimidated by him.James Potter may have been a bully when he was a teenager, but Snape grew into a bully. Snape chose the dark arts over Lily; James changed for the woman he loved. That was the difference.Not that I'm glad Snape is gone, because I think he deserved a chance to redeem himself to Harry or prove that he wasn't evil, but I after going through all the tormenting with Harry though the books, I just can't bring myself to forgive him as Harry did.Harry, you are a much more forgiving person than I.Minerva McGonagall:She is such a savage, this lady. Her wizard mind tricks (and physical tricks) are what make her so cool. My love for her can't be expressed in words. And when she was upset about Harry, I loved her even more.She is such a fierce lady and she should he headmaster. I don't know what I would do without her. Haha.Voldemort:He comes last. Ol' Voldy. Probably the most evil of them all. Except for Umbridge of course. But this isn't about her.I think that he thought what he was doing was ok. He thought it was for the good of the Wizarding World. It was not, but he didn't know. His childhood and adulthood were demented and tortured. He didn't know what was wrong and what was right.Harry gave him a chance to apologize for his wrongdoings. Harry gave him a chance to be human again.Voldemort didn't want to be human. He wanted to be the monster he was. But in the end, he died with "mundane finality", showing that he was really just Tom Riddle.Author:Good old JK. She is so brilliant. Her story is an inspiring one that proves to everyone that nothing is really impossible if you have enough nerve. If we're quoting Ginny.She went through such a dark time, but she turned it around. Now she is a wife, a mother, she is happy. And that's all anyone could ever ask for: happiness.Recommended To:I doubt there are many people who haven't read Harry Potter, but I didn't read it for the first time until now, and that's WAY behind everyone else, just like I tell you about below. But everyone needs to read these books.Overall:This was my last read of 2015. It was a great finale. The twists, the turns, and the loops send you for a wild ride in this book. I could not have asked for a better conclusion to Harry Potter and to 2015.I am definitely glad I read them. Most people read these when they were 9 or 10. I did start the first book in 3rd or 4th grade, I think, but I didn't really enjoy it. Now, I am glad I picked them up. Thank God for my neighbor who lent them and the movies to me or I never would have gone back to these books. I would have remembered picking them up and ended it there. Now I have completed the reading, no matter how long it took me, but it finally happened!I may not have grown up with these books or had them shape my life, but they have built within me a deeper appreciation for literature itself, those who did shape their lives around these books, and for the great novelty of this series.Everyone needs to know the story of Harry Potter, his friends, his family, his determination, his passion, his forgiveness, his selflessness, his bravery, his sacrifice, and most of all, his strength. Because his strength, will make you stronger. And everyone could use a little more strength.For lack of any possibly better word, this was a truly magical series.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: Relevance AlertThis is not a review of the book.My comments specifically relate to a scene in and a song from the soundtrack to the first Deathly Hallows film.Sexuality Content WarningI originally posted a version of my comments in a GR discussion about sexuality and Harry Potter.If you are the sort of reader who thinks these two issues should never be associated with each other, please do not read on. I don't want to spoil your world view.Sexuality, Adolescence and Harry PotterOne of the funny things about the original discussion and the response to it is the lack of recognition of how important sexuality actually (and overtly) is to HP, especially later in the series.It defies me how people expect someone to write about or think about or progress through adolescence without considering sex or sexuality.Heartstring Wands and Love TrianglesFor me, HP is a love triangle in which there is enormous sexual tension around who will end up with Hermione by the time they escape the chains of adolescence.Obviously, JKR for her own reasons avoids the obvious temptation to let Harry end up with Hermione.However, right up until the last moment, there is some doubt as to whether Ron will get the girl.It's totally misguided to think that HP's adolescent audience isn't right on top of this issue.In fact, they're probably way ahead of most adults in the audience (including me).Let's DanceIn the first Deathly Hallows film, Harry and Hermione dance together, while Ron remains banished in the wild.This was a tipping point in the story, when Hermione might possibly have reversed her sexual selection.When I saw the film, a whole group of kids burst out laughing in this scene.I still don't know whether I missed something (was it Harry's seriousness or clumsiness?), but I was too busy concentrating on the soundtrack and trying to work out its significance.The Ship Song[I wrongly thought] the song was Nick Cave's "The Ship Song", which was the last thing I expected to hear in a HP film.It's a great melody, but if you have a look at the lyrics, you have to wonder what was intended by the director, at least.http://www.stlyrics.com/songs/n/nickc...Did Harry create a "little mystery" with Hermione?Did Hermione loose her dogs on Harry? Or let her hair hang down?Did Harry have to remove her wings, so that she could try to fly in her own right?Did Hermione have to escape Harry's legendary pull, so she could find happiness?I wish I could have asked those kids.Post Script:I just asked my 12 year old daughter why people laughed at that scene, and she said (in this order) "because they weren't together" (i.e., a recognised couple) and "because they were goofy". Original Review: February, 2011

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: Re, re, re... re-read! As you can see, this is not the first time I’ve re-read this amazing series. However, I think it is the first time I’ve done all seven books in one month, and it is glorious! Somehow, the film versions have a tendency to assert themselves in my recollection, and although I do really like them, and have visited the studios several times to great fun, they are not as good as the novels, especially from book 4 onward. All those little details, and well, the big ones of course, make all the difference. I absolutely LOVE this world and characters and shall keep coming back :O)------------The final book!Gosh, I can remember actually queueing for this one at Waterstones Piccadilly, something I had never done before (or since) but it was too big an event to miss. I arrived late evening and spent the next 7 hours with people of all ages and nationalities, all enamoured with Rowling's characters. It was absolutely brilliant!!!!!So, anyway, what about the book? Following on from the Half-Blood Prince, this last instalment is full of action, suspense, revelations and battles. It is war, after all. Some people do the right thing for the wrong reason, or indeed the wrong thing for the right one. Many scenes echo the ones seen in the Philosopher’s Stone, with visits to Diagon Alley, Gringots Bank, the Sorting Hat, Olivander, the four school Houses, Hogwarts’s Ghosts, etc. Our trio has a hard time finding out what to do - which items did Voldemort choose for his Horcruxes and where could they be? And what are the Deathly Hallows? - but that just made it more believable.The characterisation was spot on, not just for our group, but also for Dumbledore, who comes across as being much more complex (and flawed) than imagined. Our favourite teachers are still there and we finally find out Snape’s secret. And Neville, my favourite secondary character, shows his mettle and shines! His gran appears here too and what a spunky sight she is!A word about Molly Weasley as promised. I loved that Rowling went against the stereotype of making her ‘weak' as would be suggested by her motherly behaviour. In fact, Molly is one hell of a strong witch as becomes apparent in this book, and which was hinted in the series by the many parallels shown with Ginny. It seems the girls ‘have' it in the Weasley family. In fact, Rowling tackles quite a few roles. In her universe, it is ok to be intelligent, love books and the library, or be the funny sidekick, or the shy one, or the slightly weird one. Courage comes in many guises and can be found in the seemingly most unlikely places. Finally, I truly love this series and shall keep coming back to it, again and again, to lose myself in this incredible and amazing universe full of beloved characters. Although I haven’t given all the books the maximum score, the series as a whole definitely deserves the 5 stars :O)

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: Trigger warnings: death, death of a loved one, violence, physical injury, hate speak about minority groups, torture, physical abuse.25/11/2019I cried five times on the tram reading the last 75 pages of this. 31/12/2018I managed to get through 57 pages of this last night and then powered through the rest from 5.30pm onwards, finishing it at 11.17pm, a whole 43 minutes before I needed to have it finished. *high fives self*This time around, I cried over the Weasleys giving Harry a watch for his 17th birthday because he has no one else to perform the tradition for him. Ow, my feelings.(P.S. Someone throw Snape in the dumpster on their way out, thx)21/10/2017I started a marathon reread of the Harry Potter series thirteen days ago in preparation for a Harry Potter trivia night (we came second, for those of you who care). I made it to within 15 pages of the end before I had to run out the door or risk missing the tram. HARRUMPH. Anyway. I finished my marathon reread when I got home from trivia at 11pm. I cried over the scene between Harry and Ron. Again. I cried over Fred. Again. I *nearly* cried over Luna and the patronuses scene again, and only didn't because I already had my make up on and no time to fix it if I ended up with mascara all over my damn face. I love everything about this freaking book. The end. 24/12/2016I cried. Again. But over weird things this time?? I cried over the scene where Harry's struggling to produce a patronus because it's the middle of the Battle of Hogwarts and he can't think of anything happy, and Luna - patronus leading the way - tells him that they're all still there, they're all still fighting. FEELINGS. FEEEEEEEEEEEEEEELINGS. 31/12/2015Frankly, I'm impressed that I managed to cram this one into the last three days of the year, because I desperately wanted to finish the series this year. And I did - with four hours to spare. *high fives self*For some reason, this reread brought a hell of a lot of emotions with it. The developing relationship between Ron and Hermione gave me feels. Harry's reaction to Lupin turning up gave me feels. All the deaths gave me feels, obviously. Neville proving himself to be a true Gryffindor and his grandmother's pride in him gave me feels. McGonagall's pride and heartbreak over Harry gave me feels. Dumbledore's backstory gave me feels. And I may have broken down and sobbed during the scene between Ron and Harry that I mentioned below. Basically, this book is perfection, and it's hands down my favourite of the series. Now let's just go ahead and pretend that Snape redemption plot never happened... 29/6/2014Everything I said last time around still stands. But one of the things I find most interesting about Deathly Hallows is getting to see the other side of Dumbledore. In the other six books, he's basically presented as this massive force for good, who would never make dubious decisions or do the wrong thing or endanger his students. But here? Here we see that Dumbledore operated in the grey areas of morality as much as anyone. Which is one of those interesting things that comes with age - realising that your teachers and your heroes aren't infallible. They're human. 18/3/2013There are literally no words for how much I adore this book. It takes a lot in a book to make me cry (almost nothing, however, when it comes to movies and TV shows...), and yet Deathly Hallows reduces me to a weeping mess every time I read it. That said, the epilogue grates a little more every time - it just feels slightly sloppy or a little too neat and tidy or SOMETHING.That said, I love how there are so many tendrils to the story that have been gradually developed over the previous six books, and how expertly they're all pulled together here. Neville becomes more of a BAMF with every reading, and I will never not cheer for Molly Weasley screaming "NOT MY DAUGHTER, YOU BITCH" at Bellatrix. While I know a lot of people get all "Harry Potter and the Prolonged Camping Trip" about the central portion of the book, those same people likely would have been upset or annoyed if they had, as Harry yells at Ron, been finding a Horcrux a week and home safe and sound by Christmas. Besides, the prolonged camping trip leads to what is arguably my favourite moment in the entire series - Ron destroying the locket, then breaking down in tears, and Harry saying "She's like my sister. I love her like a sister and I reckon she feels the same way about me. It's always been like that. I thought you knew." It's such a simple moment, such a small thing. But for me, it says so much about Ron, about Harry, and about the honesty that underpins their friendship. In summary, twenty years from now, people will say to me "After all this time?". And my reply will be "Always."

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: Of course it is happening inside your head, Harry, but why on earth should that mean that it is not real?It is neither my first read nor the second, and yet this time around it proved to be even more difficult for me to read. Especially Deathly Hallows. First, as an "semi" adult (I'm not that old, bless my soul), I am more comfortable with my emotions, so that I was able to connect with (not joking) every single character. And second, the last time I read this book was in my high school years, and as such the actual (and horribe) death toll of the war was long forgotten. For the most part, it was like experiencing those deaths for the first time (yet again). And while I was aware of the main deaths (I could never forgot those), their loss was even harder for me to bear. It's like every emotion in me has doubled (or even tripled) in intensity. I usually devour books in the blink of an eye, but alas, JKR had other plans in mind while writing this book. Any attempt made by me at continuous reading was repeatedly and mercilessly thwarted by my constant need to ugly cry every other page or so.Regardless of the drama and all the controversies involving JKR at the moment, there is absolutely no doubt that she is a literary genius. HP shaped our generation by instilling in its readers values of the utmost importance, and which are sadly diminishing in recent years. I have no doubt in my heart that these books would continue to live on forever, existing as a part of our culture for eternity⚠️SPOILERS⚠️_____________________________I'm truly at a loss for wordsJKR just killed my man😭😭😭😭😭😭DO YOU WANT ME TO HAVE A HEART ATTACK ?!MY DEATH WOULD BE ON YOUR CONSCIENCE JKRThat is one of the most tragic backstories out thereI'm emotionally traumatized, stuck in a catatonic statePLEASE HELP MEMy brain:My heart:_____________________________Excuse my bluntness but McGonagall is one of the best fucking BAMF out thereI need a book with HER as the MCI mean, just look at her, I would follow her into battle smiling(#^&^#*&($@*^$(^@FINALLYIT'S ABOUT DAMN TIMEThis one really hit homeThe twins were my favorite characters, I loved them so muchThey were THE best characters, every scene with them was a laughJust WHY ?! Why ?!?Why not kill off Percy instead??? Give him a heroic death to redeem himself?? WHY DID YOU HAVE TO HURT MY BABYS WHYI can't stop crying HELP ME 😭😭😭😭_____________________________Over a decade later and I still can't believe that JKR actually followed through with itI'd rather see everyone else dropping dead and having eternal world-domination by death eatersBut please let Dobby livePLEASEI need thisMy soul needs thisWHY DID HE HAVE TO DIE ????? WHY ?!??!!??!!? 😭😭😭😭I wish that scene was in the book too T_TJust when I thought I couldn't love Hermione any more..Quick question: why do you think Draco intentionally acted as if he couldn't recognize the trio at the Malfoys manor?Conclusions:1. I love book Ron. I hate movie Ron.2. I ship Ron and Hermione in the books. I ship Harry and Hermione in the movies.I'M FEELING SO CONFLICTED__________________________________WHY !!! WHY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!Literally every page makes me cry__________________________________How the hell am I supposed to keep my mental health intact after reading this shit ?? I can't 😭😭_________________________________________________________24 hours later and I'm STILL not over it 😭😭 my heart aches 😢HOW DARE U BITCH, HOW DARE U Someone should take her Quick-Quotes Quill and shove it up her assI want to take a moment to appreciate how special and unique Luna is ❤My little brother made me add that image for no good reason other than it's pretty and crazy ass Bellatrix is there *you owe me one*I DON'T GIVE A DAMN ABOUT HIS INNOCENCE JKR BRING HEDWIG BACK___________________________________________I just want to say that Regulus deserved BETTER, he redeemed himself in the best of ways I think. He tried to save the entire world, without expecting any glory or recognition in return. AND KREACHER CRYING 😢REALLY Rowling? REALLY ?! 😭This scene REALLY REALLY broke my heart. Big D is able to see past the lies his parents fed him with his entire life. Perfect closure. I really wanted Petunia to say some nice things to Harry as well, but I felt that it would probably be extremely OOC for her to do so :/ I understand she was jealous of Lily for being a witch and took it out on her son, a constant presence and a constant reminder of what she could never have and could never be. BUT i was just sobbing SO damn much by the time she said "goodbye", I kind of understand why she is so bitter about it. It doesn't justify her abusing Harry though. So tragic. Some characters would NEVER get their HEA 😢__________________________________Decided to replenish my supply of tissues, diet coke, and Doritos. It's not enough. This book is going to kill me. 💔I've decided that the only way for me to cope with the heartache is looking up fanart of scenes that really made me emotional so I could cry and cry and cry until I'm all out of tears and finally ready to pick up the book again. So please excuse my constant updating of this review. It's more for myself than anything. But if some of you would enjoy it, then all the better 🤧So it's pretty obvious, but well... ⚠️SPOILERS⚠️

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: What can I say but genius? All along I have considered myself a mild Harry Potter fan, but once you get to the end and Rowling wraps up all the minute details she plants from book one you cannot help but be amazed at her creativity. Building on each of the books, writing each one at a slightly higher level as the characters grow up, all the details, and lets not forget the insignificant matter of the entire world evolving to hold a joint consciousness of Harry Potter. Children's literature has boomed and for that alone I give her immense credit. We are finally rewarded with Ron and Hermione. I am finally justified in Snape being my favorite character. We get to see the emotion to McGonagall and the history of Dumbledore. And of course, we finally, after 4100 pages, get to see the face off between good and evil, see what powers truly lie in Harry, and discover how strong our own allegiance to the boy really are. Rowling satisfies both camps on Harry's fate (without having to scar the boy with a task like Snape's) and even me who cared more about Snape's destiny than Harry's.  Yes the book is long and there are a few scenes in the Forest of Deans and at Bill & Fleur's that drag, but they are spaced out and there is so much else packed in to reward you for a few pages spent just as frustrated as the hero trio. Besides my favorite scene happens in that lonely forest when Harry finds the sword. But once the action winds back to Hogwarts, the book is nearly impossible to put down. The wand loyalties could have been explained better, but overall the complexity of the plot and resolution were impressive.The emotion in the book is so strong. Maybe it's that after all these years and all these books, you feel so committed to the characters, but you can't help but feel so full of emotion, and even I'll admit it cry, at the height of the story. I don't think there's an emotion you don't feel in reading this book, but the strongest one is in the end when you have to close the book and say goodbye to the chapter in your life tied up in the story. I can't read this book without feeling sad at the end that it is over.My favorite thing about book 7 is the way it ends, back at King's Cross where your view shifts from seeing Harry's adventures as a lost 11-year-old about to have a fantastic journey to a caring adult guiding a broken boy through the pain and challenges he is about to endure and conquer on this spectacular journey. What can I say but genius?

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: I waited 9 years for Rowling to do the right thing and kill off the Christ Figure, you know, like the *professional* writers do. Don't get me wrong, Harry was my favorite character--brave, deeply loyal, naturally talented--all wonderful qualities not meant for this foul Earth. I wanted him to die in his prime, to be celebrated in song, like all the great heros before him. Alas...Rowling didn't write so much a novel, as she did a Hollywood screenplay! Complete with lame wincing juvenile lines like the one uttered by Molly Weasley to Bellatrix LeStrange in the Battle for Hogwarts, "Not my daughter, you BITCH!" A line meant to draw applause, cheers, and laughter from a bunch of teenagers in a darkened movie theater, not a line that would have been used by the prim and proper mother, Molly Weasley, that we grew to know and love in books 1-6.The book could have been better edited as there were long stretches of BORING reading throughout. It's as if Rowling just ran out of creative juices in the end and chose to let her fans write the final book for her. She inserted "PotterWatch" as a nod to the PotterCasters(PotterCast and MuggleCast), and she wrote in a nude scene for Harry Potter, as a nod to Daniel Radcliffe's nude stint in Equus. The whole *camping out in the forest waiting for something to happen* part was NOT something I expected after Book 6, when it was shown with such great care how Voldemort had hidden the locket horcrux. I can't believe they are making 2 films out of this, the crappiest book in the series!Oh, and that Epilogue, where to begin? If Rowling sent out apology letters to all her fans for writing it, that still wouldn't be enough of an atonement! The woman should be tarred, feathered, drawn, and quartered for that criminally putrid Epilogue! The visual of a middle aged Harry Potter waiting at the train station to get to his 9 to 5 job was the let-down of the century. I loved Harry because he was special and because of his aura of destiny! I loved that, despite his emotionally abusive childhood, he chose to become a decent human being, instead of following Tom Riddle's path of evil and bitterness! I loved that, when presented with a challenge, he almost always chose to do the right and moral thing, over what was easy. I didn't want to see him become a regular, boring adult, with a lame, humdrum life, he was too talented, too moral, too heroic for all of that mundane crap!

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text:
4.5REVIEW IN ENGLISHIt all ends. This story began in 2011 when I started reading all the books for the first time, one per year. Last year I failed, but this one I fulfill my promise. I already feel nostalgia that this series is over and maybe, in many years, I'll hop back on the Hogwarts train to meet again with Harry and his friends.This book is so sad. Harry and his friends are in danger as Voldemort and the Death Eaters walk at ease, killing who they want and chasing their opponents. No one is safe. Everyone is afraid. That is why Harry is determined to finish with the task that Dumbledore left him and with the greatest secrecy, he will be in charge of eliminating the rest of the horcruxes with the help of Ron and Hermione.With more than 600 pages, we have a relative calm before things get very bad and that's why the book may have an irregular pacing. I really liked learning more about the past of characters like Albus Dumbledore and all the mystery about the Deathly Hallows. As the plot unfolds, the motivations of the characters and their relationships are developed more: tension and fear are problems for Harry and his friends and the deaths of friends and family will be hard to bear.The novel takes us to a grand finale. I only had the referent of the 2011 movie (which I saw when it came out and destroyed my poor soul) and I loved seeing how the Battle of Hogwarts differs in several points to what we saw on screen. I do not think it's a surprise for many but first I must say that I was very surprised to see how Rowling was giving explanations so everything made sense. Although sometimes I felt some details are hard to swallow, everything was explained and wrapped up in the end. Needless to say, my favorite character was always Snape (you'll know why) and if I explain why is spoiler, so I let it be.Epic moments, painful and heartfelt deaths, beautiful but sad scenes and there is also time to laugh. There's a little bit of everything. I know I'm late for the party but it's inevitable to feel sad when we get to the famous epilogue. I would have loved that the end had more pages before reaching that moment in the future. Still I believe that the ending meant the end of an era for many. And for me too.That's it. The book is as good as might be expected, with aspects that can be improved, but a worthy conclusion to a saga that marked a whole generation of children like me. Of course I recommend it.PS: I'm NOT going to read Harry Potter and the cursed child. I consider it a nonsense the size of a Hungarian dragon.PS: How amazing is Minerva McGonagall. She deserves an altar like, NOW.********************************RESEÑA EN ESPAÑOLTodo termina. Y también mi viaje por esta saga. Para muchos no es sorprendente que reseñe este libro, 
  pero esta historia empezó en 2011 cuando empecé a leer cada uno de estos libros por primera vez, uno por año.
 
  El año pasado me descaché y no leí este y ahora con algo de tardanza cumplo la lectura.
 Ya siento la nostalgia de que se ha acabado y que tal vez, en muchos años, vuelva a subirme al tren de Hogwarts para reunirme de nuevo con Harry y sus amigos.Este libro es sobradamente triste. Harry y sus amigos están en peligro ya que Voldemort y los mortífagos caminan a sus anchas, 
  asesinando a quien quieren y persiguiendo a sus opositores. 
Nadie está a salvo. Todos tienen miedo. Por eso él está empecinado en terminar con la tarea que Dumbledore le encargó y con el mayor secretismo
   se encargará de eliminar los horrocruxes que le faltan con ayuda de Ron y Hermione.
Este libro también lo leí en inglés como el anterior. Con más de 600 páginas, en este libro pasan muchas cosas y se amplia la información de muchas otras. Tenemos una relativa calma antes de que las cosas se pongan muy mal 
  y por eso el libro puede tener un ritmo irregular.
 Me gustó mucho aprender más sobre el pasado de personajes como Albus Dumbledore y todo el misterio sobre las Reliquias de la muerte. Creo que a medida que se va desarrollando la trama se profundiza aún mas en las motivaciones de los personajes y su evolución y sus relaciones: 
  la tensión y el miedo hace mella en el trío meteórico de Harry y sus amigos 
y las muertes de amigos y enemigos harán mella en su viaje.


Yo terminando el libroLa novela va llegando a pasos agigantados para un final apoteósico. Yo solo tenía el referente de la película de 2011 (que vi cuando salió y me destrozó el alma viva) y me encantó ver como la batalla de Hogwarts se diferencia en varios puntos con respecto a lo que vimos en pantalla. No creo que sea sorpresa para muchos pero antes debo decir que me sorprendió mucho ver como Rowling fue hilando las explicaciones para que todo tuviera sentido. Aunque a veces sentí algunos detalles cogidos por los pelos (y si que le han criticado a la autora plotholes en este libro) pero creo que luego puedes aceptar todo lo que sucede. Sobra decir que mi personaje favorito de todos siempre fue Snape (ya sabrán porqué) y si me explico es spoiler, así que lo dejo estar.Sin duda hay de todo para sufrir y ser feliz. 
  Momentos épicos, muertes dolorosas y sentidas, escenas bellas pero tristes y también hay momento para reírse.
 Hay de todo un poco. Sé que llego tarde a la fiesta pero es inevitable sentirse triste cuando llegamos al famoso epílogo. Me habría encantado que el final tuviera más páginas antes de llegar a ese momento en el futuro de los personajes, ver como concluye todo de una forma más redonda. 
  Pero bueno. De resto creo que ese final significó el fin de una era para muchos. Y para mi también.
Y eso es todo. El libro es tan bueno como podría esperarse, con aspectos mejorables, pero una digna conclusión para una saga que marcó una generación entera de niños como yo. Claro que la recomiendo.
PD: 
No voy a leer el libro de Harry Potter and the cursed child. Lo considero 
  un despropósito del tamaño de un dragón húngaro.

  PD: 
Qué genial es Minerva McGonagall. 
  Un altar para esta señora YA.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: 3.25/5 starsNot a review, just a commentary since this is my 2nd time reading the series, and, well I found some issues with the last book. I know I said previously that the 1st one was my least favorite, because of how childish it was (yes, I know the first books ere geared exclusively towards middle grade audience, but still), but the last book is my least favorite because of how many problems it has. It dragged on forever... I felt I was reading it for way too long. - The first and foremost is how much overall this series has in common with LotR. And the fact that J.K. Rowling denies being inspired by him at all (maybe in her subconscious, but she didn't mean to were her words in an interview - pleaseeeeee). But that's probably a topic for another place and another time. - The part of the trio being on the run was extremely over stretched and plain boring. It felt as because they were not at Hogwarts anymore and had no classes to go to, or homework to do, well they didn't know what to do with themselves. Also while all of them were good and quite brilliant while at school, on the run they seemed rather dim witted. - The fact that it was so incredibly hard for them to believe in Deathly Hallows was stupid. Wizards, goblins, unicorns, souls splitting.... all the magical stuff and they cannot believe in something just as magical?! Say what ?! - I have been liking Fleur for a while (ever since she appeared basically) but this book solidified my liking for her character. She seemed real, composed and an excellent image of a great wife. - Remus Lupin is forever my favorite character of the whole series. And while it was hard to read the part where Harry yelled at him for wanting to leave Tonks, I think that it was a great point of Rowling's saying that adults should listen to children more often, because sometimes they know what's best better than adults with all of their life experience do. - Reading second time around I have to agree with Ron. Dumbledore was quite mental. The book should have been named Dumbledore's games or something... I enjoyed Aberforth though, little that we got of him. - At the final battle of Hogwarts when house-elves joined the battle, what was up with them poking enemies with their kitchen knives??? They are house elves, they have strong magic on their own! But the best they could do is poke with knives?... what? - Voldemort is even more of a coward second time reading. - The whole book to me seemed stretched and drawn out, but I did enjoy the beginning a lot. The wedding part was very interesting. Also all of the lore on Dumbledore's and Riddle's young lives was great. And obviously Snape's (sob, sob, sob).- The epilogue, ehhh. I feel like a lot of important characters were left out of it. The whole series had such an extensive character count, and all of them were built exceptionally well. Leaving them out seemed a little like taking the chocolate chips out of chocolate chip cookies. I would much rather read about what George was doing, how were Bill and Fleur , where was Luna... than to see what cliche of names Harry + Ginny and Ron + Hermione named their kids.... That was just so unrealistic! - While I loved Ginny's character in all other books, she didn't have much page time in this book and thus was pretty blah.My WEBSITEMy INSTAGRAMMy WORDPRESS BLOG

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: Say, Harry Potter is not a movie or a series. Say, it's all real and you're part of that magical world.Say, Cedric Diggory was your boyfriend, and Voldemort killed him. Or if your a guy, Moaning Myrtle was your girlfriend and Tom Riddle set a Basilisk on her.You'll hope that DA would win over the Dark Side, and that Harry gets to punish all the Death Eaters with a hundred Cruciatus Curse-for each Death Eater that is- won't you?You'll dream for the day that you'll get to see Bellatrix and Lucius choose Killing curse just because they can't take anymore Cruciatus curse.You're so angry you wanted to kill them yourself. You want to avenge Dumbledore's death.But on your way to Hogsmeade you came across this...................[image error]Oh no!! After all these years they aren't enemies at all! They've been friends all along. All these years of believing they loathed each other. All these years and Voldemort has got a nose all along. Well Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows is something like this. All those years of waiting for that Epic epic finale, you get 2 paragraphs of a fight between Voldemort and Harry. I was expecting Harry would use the killing curse at least. But he didn't. The upside though is he used Cruciatus Curse on the Carrows. HAH!!!!! Ooohh I loved that part. Makes me swell with happiness.I don't mind that J.K killed awful lot of characters,(Although I'd be happy to exchange Cho Chang for Fred) I think it was needed to show that the war was indeed gruesome. Because to NOT kill a lot of characters will make DH a wizarding and early version of Breaking Dawn. Where all the characters lived to tell the tale. No, that would be too painfully idealistic. Idealism is not in any way J.K's way of writing. If Harry Potter was too perfect to the point of unreal-ism, then it wouldn't have been the best selling series of all times.I didn't like the ending so much. But the whole book was so great, still epic. Kept me on the edge of my seat. It would hurt me if I give HP less than five stars, and honestly it doesn't deserve anything less than 5 stars. Hell I would even give it a million stars if I could.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: 5 stars (reread).“It is a curious thing, Harry, but perhaps those who are best suited to power are those who have never sought it. Those who, like you, have leadership thrust upon them, and take up the mantle because they must, and find to their own surprise that they wear it well.”Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows follows Harry Potter, who is leaving Privet Drive for the last time. Not for his seventh year at Hogwarts, but instead, to seek out Voldemort’s Horcruxes with Ron and Hermione, to stop him once and for all. His protective charm that kept him safe at Privet Drive breaks the moment he turns seventeen, so he knows that as soon as he leaves, Voldemort and his Death Eaters won’t be far behind. Harry, Ron, and Hermione go on one last dangerous, life changing adventure, in order for Harry to meet Voldemort in one final battle.Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows is such a fantastic conclusion to this series. For a book that’s set almost entirely in the woods, it’s incredibly fast paced and packed with action. Out of all the books in this series, this one definitely has one of the darkest moods, for good reason. This book definitely isn't the usual for Harry Potter—it’s not set in Hogwarts and there’s no classes, homework, and Quidditch—but it’s still so amazing. Once again, though, J.K. Rowling takes no mercies when it comes to characters we love, and I won’t spoil it for the three people who haven’t read this series, but the deaths in this book hurt so much, even eleven years later.Can we talk about the characters for a moment? I love watching these kids grow up, especially Harry. What a brave, selfless boy. He will forever be one of my all time favorite characters in all of fiction, and it makes me so sad to see how he’s treated by most of the fandom, because he’s wonderful. He has been through so much shit in seven years and still, he doesn’t let that change who he is. He cares so much and it’s amazing to see after what he’s been through. Ron and Hermione develop so much as well, and I love seeing their friendship survive such difficult times. They all deserve so much more.“Hello, Minister!” bellowed Percy, sending a neat jinx straight at Thicknesse, who dropped his wand and clawed at the front of his robes, apparently in awful discomfort. “Did I mention I’m resigning?”I’ve said this before, but I love how easily Rowling found the balance between humorous and serious moments. This book is, of course, morbid and dark—but there’s still hilarious, light moments when you’re least expecting it. And, a lot of the time, when you really kind of need it. So much of this book is hard to read, especially considering these events are happening to teenagers, but there’s some great little moments that make it a lot easier to get through. I will forever laugh about Ron fighting his mom about having to clean his room before the wedding. These characters are so damn normal and realistic, despite it all, and I love that.I’m in the minority with this opinion, and that’s okay, but I love the ending and I always will. People claim it’s too sentimental and that it didn’t show their trauma and grief enough (as if we didn’t see enough of that in all seven books), which is ridiculous. As someone with PTSD, who has had it since I was a child, sometimes it feels like it’ll never go away. Harry learns to deal with his grief so well, and learns to deal with the death of his parents and family so well, and it ends with these kids growing up and having families and being happy. The overall theme of this series is love, and that’s what it ends on. Overall, I loved Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows as much as I always have. This is the series that made me love reading as much as I do, and that has consistently been the escape I could always turn to since I was very small child. There will never be another series that I love as much as this one, or that means to me what this one does, and I’m definitely okay with that. My rereads always go by far too quickly for my liking, but I always love it so much while it lasts. In conclusion: thank you, Harry. Until next time.“Every second he breathed, the smell of the grass, the cool air on his face, was so precious: To think that people had years and years, time to waste, so much time it dragged, and he was clinging to each second.”↠ Reread #25: February 5-6, 2019.↠ Reread #26: May 29-30, 2019.↠ Reread #27: July 16-17, 2019.↠ Reread #28: January 9-10, 2020.↠ Reread #29: March 26-27, 2020.↠ Reread #30: January 6-7, 2021.↠ Reread #31: August 29-30, 2021.↠ Reread #32: December 30-31, 2021.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: The conclusion to a truly epic series. I’m so happy I made this re-read. All the wonderful memories, the great moments now … Although I usually remember all details the first time, there were some here that I had forgotten about and revisiting them was a delight!After the death of Albus Dumbledore at the end of book #6 Harry, Ron and Hermione have not returned to Hogwarts. Instead, Harry goes back to Privet Drive one last time and then goes to the Burrow. Of course, he is being chased all the time, leading to two tragic deaths right at the beginning of the book (in fact, the casualness with which one of the two was mentioned almost broke my heart). There are some lighter moments in this that give a bit of a respite (like Bill and Fleur’s wedding), but the main tone is that of darkness, loss and action, naturally.While being on the run after the aforementioned wedding, Harry finally puts most of the puzzle pieces together (with the help of not just the smartest witch of his age but also of Kreacher who became mighty sweet) and starts the hunt for the Horcruxes. Between the mad dashes we get a lot of background story, most notably the missing pieces about Albus Dumbledore himself, all the connections to the titular Deathly Hallows and Voldemorts greatest weakness (these bits of history were actually the best part for me, always, not just now that we have the Fantastic Beasts movie(s)).Again, there are some moments that were conveyed better in the movies which came as a bit of a surprise (but it was fun seeing how the movies and books complete each other). Such as the dragon that was chained up in Gringotts giving the impression it knew exactly who freed it and that the kids were sitting on its back so it flew lower to let them off at the lake; the Patronus being such a special feat of magic that not just any happy memory will do to conjure it (a pet peeve of mine with the books ever since book #3); the Grey Lady giving Harry the riddle about the Room Of Requirement; McGonagall being even more kick-ass (without help); and probably most notably (view spoiler)[Dobby’s death that was heartbreaking in the book but translated even better in the movie (which is weird considering that Dobby hadn’t made an appearance between movies #2 and #7.1 so there was never the same kind of redemption as in the books) (hide spoiler)].What I cannot forgive, that they changed for the movies, is the story of Harry’s wand. For anyone who doesn’t remember: Harry’s wand gets snatched almost in half when Harry and Hermione make their escape from Godric’s Hollow – both in the book and the movie. The difference: in the book the core is not broken! And in the end, (view spoiler)[having the Elder Wand, Harry uses it only once – to repair his old and loyal wand (successfully) – before giving it up (in a better/more intelligent/more plausible way than in the movie as well) (hide spoiler)]. That, in my opinion, is crucial. Which is exactly why it borders on blasphemy that it was changed in the movie!Then there were moments that were brilliant but missing from the movies completely, like Neville’s gran (bwahahaha!), Dudley’s goodbye to Harry, Percy finally coming around (and the twins‘ reaction to him coming back). It was small moments like these that glued the action-packed sequences together. Because all the action and the stakes being so high, of course, means that not everyone is going to make it out alive and the readers need to care. In fact, there is quite a number of people who were important supporting characters that didn’t survive the Battle of Hogwarts (most notably (view spoiler)[Fred Weasley (hide spoiler)] for whom I mourned almost the most). And that is one of the greatest strengths of the series if you ask me: even after all these years readers like me cannot stop thinking about this world and its inhabitants, wondering what happened afterwards, obsessing over every little detail throughout the seven books/movies and never waivering in our love for it all. That love means that no matter how many times we read or listen to the books, the tragic events are never less of a blow, the funny moments are never any less funny. The writing is crisp and vivid as it was the very first time and the entire series is a fixed part of the readers‘ life (no matter how old one was when reading it for the first time).

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: I liked it. I really did. I laughed, I cheered, I said "Holy SHIT!" at least twice.... I even got a little choked up at some points. All in all, I'd say it was a successful end to the series. Ms. Rowling deserves to take a little time off and enjoy basking in the glow of the knowledge that she has not only written seven successful books in ten years, but created an entire world that is big enough to fit hundreds more.Anyway, about this actual book. It felt a lot longer than the rest of them did, probably because of the format change - no more Hogwarts, no more Quidditch, points gained, points lost, detentions with Snape and all that. Our Heroes were kept on the run for pretty much the entire book, so that by the time you get to the climax you think, "Wow, did they do all that in just 500 pages? A wedding, a break-in at the Ministry, a break-in at Gringotts, a major battle in the Malfoy mansion, a brush with death at Godrick's Hollow and all that in just 500 pages? Hot damn...."Speaking of Gringotts, that's one of the many reasons I liked this book. Rowling told us in book one that you'd have to be a fool to break into Gringotts, and most authors would require you to take it on their word. But she went and showed us, and came up with a hell of a scenario.As much fun as it was finding out that Dumbledore was just as obnoxious in his youth as most of us are was cool, it did feel a bit forced. The entire scene where Aunt Muriel lectured Doge on Dumbledore's youthful indiscretions and mysterious family goings-on should have just WARNING: EXPOSITION stamped on it in red. I'm not sure what the purpose of it was, other than to humanize Dumbledore and to give us a lead-in to the Deathly Hallows. Which I'm still of two minds about anyway. As cool as the idea was, I don't think we should have had to wait until this late in the series to find out about them. At the end of Half-Blood Prince, Harry's path is straight and sure - Horicruxes all the way - and now we have this distraction in the Hallows. Also deserving of the EXPOSITION stamp: Snape's final memories in the Pensieve and Harry's last conversation with Dumbledore.I don't know, maybe it was to give him the choice between destroying Voldemort and defeating Voldemort or something. I haven't really processed it all yet, since I did read the book at approximately Mach 4, which is not the recommended reading speed. Perhaps I'll be more comfortable with the Hallows in the re-read.And then there was the camping sequence. I get it - they're lost in more ways than one. I suspect this may have been an artifact of the one book = one year format. It was probably also meant to keep us in a sense of heightened danger, but that's pretty much where I felt the book drag.Okay, now that I'm done nit-picking...DEATH!Ms. Rowling said in an interview that this book "isn't a bloodbath."Oh really? 1. Hedwig - This was Rowling saying, "I'm not fucking around. I've just killed Harry's most faithful companion, his tether to the world in which he belongs. Imagine what else I'm planning." 2. Mad-Eye Mooney - A fallen warrior, just like the chapter title says. I think Mad-Eye would have been surprised to survive this battle - of all the Order of the Phoenix he seemed most in tune with the reality that they faced. 3. Dobby - This was where I got choked up, I don't mind telling you. Dobby didn't deserve a knife in the heart. Hell, he didn't deserve to die at all. Having said that, he died very well, and his death was handled with dignity. It was also another reminder from Rowling - "See? I killed off another completely innocent character. You people have no idea what you're in for...." 4. Wormtail - Devious bastard. Good riddance. I would have liked to have seen more of his super-hand in action, though. What was it truly capable of? 5. Crabbe - We finally hear him speak! And we find out he's been hiding his light under a bushel. Too bad it then proceeded to burn up the bushel, and the room it was in. 6. Fred - I hate being right. Dammit. 7. Snape - Ah yes, Snape. This was done well. She kept us wondering right up to the end, and it paid off. I seriously thought he was on the dark side, but that's probably because I have no faith in real human beings, much less fictional ones. Now since I'm not a fan-fictioner, or a 'shipper, I never caught on to the idea that Snape and Lily might have had any relationship prior to Hogwarts. I thought her reaction to James' hazing was simply out of compassion for her fellow human being. I had no idea. Anyway, it's good to be wrong. Knowing everything will certainly make re-reads a little more interesting.... 8. Remus and 9. Tonks - There seems to be a lot of anger out there about the way they died - off-screen and without much impact. A lot of people appear to have a lot invested in their relationship, which surprised me. I thought they were an interesting couple, and the idea of their child was very fertile ground for future storytelling, but their relationship was never a central storyline to begin with. Every step of it was happing without the reader's knowledge. It was just revealed to us through Harry. Their courtship, their wedding, their child and their death, none of it was meant to be - and I know I'm going to get snapped at for this - important. They were a nice couple, but as we've already seen, "nice" doesn't exempt you from dying in this book. If you want to get analytical about it, it is probable that the orphaning of young Ted Lupin was meant to provide a positive mirror to Harry's own experience: here is another child of a wizarding family whose parents were taken from him before he even knew who they were. Unlike Harry, though, Ted will have a loving, supportive extended family to look after him and see that he's brought up right. For his part, Harry will be able to redeem Sirius in that he can be the godfather that Sirius never was. So while the deaths of Remus and Tonks was regrettable, it was not wrong. 10. Colin Creevey - The grace note. One last reminder from Rowling that she plays no favorites with the supporting cast, and a reminder that being innocent and nice and likable won't be enough to save you. See Remus and Tonks. 11. Voldemort - Definitely dead, if the epilogue is to be believed. So there.That's a pretty impressive body count, not including all the nameless characters who died and the people who only got seriously maimed. And it was this willingness to be brutal to her characters that made me love Rowling all the more....Let's see, what else.... Yes, Mrs. Weasley is my hero, and hopefully we can get Sigourney Weaver to play her in the movie. And Neville finally lived up to his promise. He could have been in Harry 's place, and he finally proved that he could have been every bit the hero that Harry was. Bravo for him. And his grandmother kicks ass in every way, shape and form....I loved the callback to Sorcerer's Stone. In that book, Harry, Ron and Hermione were trying to get past Devil's Snare, which can be repelled by fire. Hermione laments that they don't have any wood, to which Ron replies, "have you gone mad? Are you a witch or not?" In this book, while trying to get past the Whomping Willow, Ron moans that if they only had Crookshanks with them, they could hit the secret knot and freeze the limbs. To which Hermione replies, "Crookshanks? Are you a wizard or what?" Bless Rowling's heart for trusting us to be paying enough attention to get that joke.I really wish we could have seen Dolores Umbridge get her comeuppance. Imagine this scene from chapter 31, The Battle of Hogwarts.... Umbridge dashed as quickly as her legs would take her through the carnage. She was nearly hit by blast after blast of green light coming from wands carelessly aimed. Her thoughts ran on one track - I have to get out of here. She turned the corner and ran into a resilient, pinkish wall. She barely had time to register what it was before Grawp clenched his fist around her. "Release me!" she screamed. "I am the senior assistant to the Minister of -" And then Grawp ate her.Ahh, the poetry. She was an evil word-that-rhymes-with-runt and deserved to be punished.Oh, also, Pansy Parkinson: "But he's right there!" Winner of Hogwarts' first Slowest on the Uptake Award. That was a great moment. I would have liked to have seen a few of her fellow Slytherins stand up as well, but I guess it's tough to go against your own House.The epilogue was a good idea, if rushed. There was a flood of information that needed to be processed in only a few pages, and I see no reason why she couldn't have let it out for a few more pages. It's not like we were going to get to "Nineteen Years Later...." and just give up because the epilogue was too long. But it serves its purpose - it lets us know that after all that we'd seen, everything eventually works out. Not right away, and not perfectly - note that after all the talk about not allowing themselves to be divided, there are still houses at Hogwarts and Slytherin is still the "evil" one - but all in all everything's okay.Which brings us to my final thought, at least for now: I said at the beginning that Rowling has earned herself a nice break. She's put in a lot of work and reaped massive rewards, both tangible and intangible. But I suspect that she won't be able to rest for long. There is so much Story there, just waiting to be told. The fans will certainly take a stab at it, and I wouldn't be surprised if someone's already written a threesome between Albus Potter, Scorpius Malfoy and Teddy Lupin.Anyway, that's a whole lot more than I was planning to write, and I'm pretty sure I left things out. But there it is, my thoughts on Deathly Hallows. A good end to a good series.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: I just completely finished this series for the first time ever and it feels so so weird to say it out loud. I loved every single one of these books with all my heart and I can't believe I've waited this long to actually get around to finishing them. But now that I did...WOW, DOES IT FEEL GOOD. As many and as powerful as the deaths were in this book, the moment when Harry is forced to confront it himself, forced to feel the fear and crippling anxiety and horror that comes with the inevitability of death, the moment when he asks the ones he loves who have already passed on if it hurts and if they'll stay with him, THAT was what had me in tears more than anything. THAT was the moment that had my family giving me strange looks. But to hell if I regret a single bit of it.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: Re-read 1/7/2019 First read of 2019! Of course it had to be HP. This whole book is a sob fest. I swear I started crying from page 1. book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: *dissolves into a puddle of feels*I don’t think that any book series in this world means as much to me as Harry Potter does. I grew up reading the books and watching the movies and now that I’ve finally re-read all of them after 11 long years, it’s safe to say that these books, every single one of them, will always be a part of me. Thank you for everything, JK Rowling. I can’t praise this series highly enough, for sometimes there’s just no words to express your gratitude.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: 1 million/5I honestly have no words for how much I love this series and how much it means to me. I don't know how to write a review for this. It's like writing a review of my childhood. How do you even do that? These characters have been a part of my life for almost 18 years now. No shame, I cry every time I read this book, especially when I finish it. Despite the fact that I have still not gotten over certain deaths, this will forever be my favourite last book in a series.

text: As usual, the most brilliant conclusion to a series ever written.
