book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: REVIEW (2018):— The dedication of this book is split in seven ways: to Neil, to Jessica, to David, to Kenzie, to Di, to Anne, and to you, if you have stuck with Harry until the very end. - I am already crying, great.— Draco got in way over his head and he truly deserved better; he overestimated himself, didn’t know what he got himself into when he accepted to be a Death Eater (not that he had much of a choice to begin with) but seeing him suffer and struggle upon the sight of his teacher dangling upside down over the dinner table at Malfoy’s Manor is just too much; he actually fell out of his chair when Voldy killed her, bless his soul — Lucius thought deadass that Voldy would give him his wand lmao bye — Harry unpacking his trunk completely for the first time since he had packed it six years ago was so nostalgic for me, all the things he found like Quidditch robes, Potter Stinks bages, the photo album from Hagrid - good times! — Vernon refusing to take refuge thinking that Harry was after his house, lmao this man never fails to surprise me with his stupidity and audacity — Dudley really came thru in the end and I am happy for him; the fact that he thought Harry would actually come with them just broke my heart a little bit; I have this head canon that Dudley’s daughter was a witch and that he thus kept up with Harry later in life (I don’t care what JK says…) — I wish Petunia would’ve come thru as well, it is apparent that he wants to wish Harry good luck or at least tell him to stay safe… I don’t know, man, I wish she would’ve put down her guard at least once in her life; Lily was her sister for fuck’s sake — Harry showing Hedwig the cupboard in which he used to sleep (because he didn’t own her then)… oh my god, right in the feels, this whole farewell from Privet Drive scene had me in tears — all the “fake Potters” stripping naked when changing clothes and the real Harry wishing that they would show more privacy LOL — Hagrid actually launching himself off the bike to prevent a Death Eater from attacking Harry (he is sooo pure!) and then Harry actually using Accio Hagrid to prevent him from falling to his death, this sho was a wild ride — Harry shouting at Andromeda because he thought it was her sister Bellatrix and Ted deadass intercepting: “And that’s my wife you’re shouting at.” LOL Harry is the king of awkward first impressions :D — “Followed by five, injured two, might’ve killed one.” - Kingsley really is that bitch — Arthur having no fucking time for Kingsley’s and Lupin’s bullshit of testing who’s an impostor, because he just wants to get to his injured son - I love it when Arthur comes thru <3— “You’ll be able to tell us apart now, anyway, Mum.” - sad Molly couldn’t make use of that for long since Fred died, Rowling, you cold-hearted hoe…— Tonks being Mad-Eye’s protégée at the Ministry <3 — Ron comforting Hermione when Harry upset her by talking about Mad-Eye’s death, looking all smug with himself - Romione is really sailing at this point ! — Hermione packing Hogwarts: A History for the trip despite not really needing it because “even if we’re not going back there, I don’t think I’d feel right if I didn’t have it with me.” - I CRY BUT ALSO #ME — Hermione getting the Horcrux books out of Dumbledore’s office by simply using a summoning charm - Dumby’s such a hoe lmao — after splitting yourself you can put yourself back together by feeling remorse - WTF? — Charlie being Best Man at Bill’s wedding - I really needed more insight into the lives of the oldest Weasley boys, I love them so much — Molly giving Harry a watch for his birthday (like it is tradition when one becomes of age) and Harry just appreciating all she did for him over the years, I cry — Ron confronting Harry about “playing with Ginny’s feelings” - ugh, I understand everyone really — I know I pointed it out before but the female characters (especially Hermione) are crying all the damn time and it’s starting to piss me off a little bit — “It’s time you learned some respect.” - “It’s time you earned it.” - Harry really wasn’t playing around, he deadass snapped back to the fucking Minister, we stan a sass queen — Harry having to disguise himself with Polyjuice Potion so that he could attend the wedding — Fred saying “When I get marries, I won’t be bothering with all of this nonsense.” kills me. You won’t get married, son, you is deeeadd… — Luna recognising Harry despite the Polyjuice Potion, she truly is a queen <3 — Hermione getting excited over Viktor attending the wedding, and Ron finally owning up to his shit and asking her to dance in front of him - YEEES! — Fred and George and the Veela cousins … those misfits :> — I deadass didn’t know that Bill’s “real” name is William, I am shooketh — those drunk old men leering at Hermione in London, ugh, they creeped and annoyed the shit out of me — Hermione can do a talking Patronus and I love her for being such a talented and dedicated queen — Voldy forcing Draco to torture the people who don’t carry out his orders well enough; DRACO DID NOT DESERVE THIS ! — Sirius putting up pictures of Muggle girls in bikinis on his wall, m’boy had no chill :D — “The letter was an incredible treasure, proof that Lily Potter had lived, really lived, that her wand hand had once moved across this parchment, tracing ink into these letters, these words, words about him, Harry, her son.” <333 — Krachers tale is one of the most heartbreaking and Kreacher is deadass one of my favorite characters; when he kept saying “Master Regulus told Kreacher to come back.” I just cried and cried; Kreacher’s burden over the years (dealing with Regulus’ death, not being able to carry out his last wish/order, not being allowed to tell anyone about it), oh my lord, I want good things for him <3 — Harry giving Kreacher Regulus’ locket and Kreacher breaking down for nearly half an hour <3 — “I’ll teach you my family tree so you can answer questions on it.” - Ron really is so fucking pure in his concern for Hermione (as the Ministry was punishing Muggleborns) is so fucking sweet. — Harry and Lupin’s fight was so vicious, Lupin being ashamed of being a werewolf and Harry saying that he is actually ashamed of him because he is such a shitty dad/husband, m’boyyy— Kreacher attacking the shit out of Mundungus is my aesthetic (When Harry forbid him to hit Dung with the sauce pan again, Kreacher deadass replied: “Perhaps just once more, Master Harry, for good luck?”) I MEAN HOW CAN YOU NOT LOVE HIM? — “I insist!” said Hermione aggressively, shaking the bag of pastilles in his face. - their plan for getting into the Ministry is so wild but this particular line just cracked me up :D — Hermione being so clever as to duplicate the locket (after stealing it) so that Umbridge won’t notice it’s gone immediately, I love this gurl — Harry stealing Mad-Eye’s eye from Umbridge’s office and burying it properly <3 — “I get it. You choose him.” - ugh this whole parting of ways was unnecessary, I want my trio to stick togetherrr— Harry actually expecting Hermione to leave him as well because she’s had enough just killed me, he’s always so unsure about himself and how much people really love him — the memorial of Harry, James and Lily in Godric’s Hollow made me tear up, they fucking deserve that statue <33 and their actual house with all of those well-wishes… ah I am tearing up again — Harry reliving the scene of his parents’ death through Voldy’s memory of it… so fucking brutal (I think it’s crazy tho that Voldy was willing to spare Lily, a Muggleborn, just for Snape…) — “Do you mind if I talk to you?” - Hermione feeling super guilty because of Harry’s broken wand… she deserved better, it’s not her fault — Grindelwald was actually Bathilda’s great nephew; and his fling with Dumbledore only lasted for two months … I thought it was much longer lol — “I came running after you! I called you! I begged you to come back!” - I really do feel Hermione’s anger in this scene — Ron admitting that he went to Bill and Fleur after he deserted the trio, and Bill not being impressed with him but also not giving him a hard time - IN THIS HOUSE, WE STAN BILL WEASLEY — The Cloak = Hermione ; The Wand = Ron ; The Stone = Harry ; that moment was actually funny but their desires really reflect their personalities well — Luna’s room decoration (friends, friends, friends) … I cry — Harry having to flee from Hogwarts after throwing a fucking ”Support Harry Potter” Party at his hut - I love my man BUT WHAT IS WRONG WITH YOU??? Protect yo self and yo students… — Harry using Voldemort’s name even though Ron told him it’s a taboo - ughhh, stupid boyyy — Draco refusing to confirm that the caught Potter (his “maybes” really broke my heart)… I truly feel like Draco doesn’t need a redemption arc, there’s nothing to be bitter about without him, he’s just a boy who got in way over his head — Pettigrew being strangled by Voldy’s hand in his one true moment of pity… serves him right I don’t even care — Harry seeing Voldy punishing those who were left at Malfoy Manor … My heart truly bleeds for Draco — Harry finally being able to shut his mind from Voldemort by feeling extreme pain (at the loss of Dobby) :( It all comes with a great price … — “Mudblood and proud of it.” - I LOVE HERMIONE MORE THAN LIFE ITSELF — “So young,” he finally said, “to be fighting so many.” - one of my fave quotes <3 — Bill and Fleur give me so many good and wholesome vibes, they are deadass my favourite couple from the series (Fleur not being able to eat when Bill is on duty; Bill making sure Griphook treats her right and all of that… I love them!) — Lupin appointing Harry godfather <3 — Harry using the Imperius Curse to carry out with their scheming at Gringotts… ugh, the sacrifices he made… (this book is really about the loss of innocence…) — Aberforth trying to keep an eye out for Harry (Albus had told him about the mirror) - I do love him a lot — “He left me a job.” - “Did he, now?” said Aberforth. “Nice job, I hope? Peasant? Easy? Sort of thing you’d expect an unqualified wizard kid to be able to do without overstretching themselves?” - Aberforth is a sass queen and I stan him — the reconciliation of the Golden and Silver Trio at Hogwarts made me so happy; I really need Book 7 from the perspective of Neville, Luna and Ginny !!! — The reason why most of the students survived so well is because they were purebloods and the Carrows didn’t wanna spill too much of their blood… so fucking crazy, let’s talk about privilege, huh — AUGUSTA LONGBOTTOM, I WOULD DIE FOR YOU! The fact that she finally told Neville that she was proud of him for sticking up to the Death Eaters and that he was truly his parents’ son… All the tears were flowing! — Neville found the passage to the Hog’s Head by thinking he was hungry inside of the Room of Requirements #me — “So, what’s the plan, Harry?” said George. “There isn’t one,” said Harry. “Just going to make it up as we go along, are we? My favorite kind,” said Fred. - I LOVE EVERYONE — “Why would Harry Potter try to get inside Ravenclaw Tower? Potter belongs to my house!” I love Minnie and her pride. <3 — Harry using the Cruciatius curse on Amycus because he spit in Minnie’s face - HOLY COW — “I shall expect you and the Slytherins in the Great Hall in 20 minutes,” said Professor McGonagall. “If you wish to leave with your students, we shall not stop you. But if any of you attempt to sabotage our resistance, or take up arms against us within this castle, then, Horace, we duel to kill.” - MINNIE DID NOT COME TO PLAY ! — “I was a fool!” Percy roared. - I was waiting for this reconciliation and it’s so pure, I love it! Especially the fact that he individually apologised to Mr Weasley. <3 — The Bloody Baron stabbed Helena Ravenclaw because she refused his advances; overcome with grief he then killed himself — “Have you seen my grandson?” “He’s fighting.” “Naturally,” said the old lady proudly. “Excuse me, I must go and assist him.” - Augusta and Neville are my faves <33 — Ron lifting Hermione off her feet out of enthusiasm bc she kissed him is #me I LOVE THEM — Crabbe using Avada Kedavra on Hermione… that fucking hoe! — FRED FRED FRED FRED FRED FRED FRED FRED - YOU DESERVED BETTER! — Trelawney dumping crystal balls on Death Eaters - we stan a queen — the fact that Dumbleodre was not in his fucking frame when Harry came to put Snape’s memory in the Pensieve is so fucking typical… that man is one huge let down — ”It’s real for us.” I totally forgot that this was Snape’s line… <333 as you know, I hate adult!Snape but kid!Snape is fucking precious and I love his first years of friendship with Lily!! — “Come on, Severus, let’s find another compartment.” - Lily truly was that queen <3— when Snape first attended Hogwarts, Lucius was a prefect WTF ? — YOU RAISED HIM LIKE A PIG FOR SLAUGHTER? Snape really told Dumby how it is… — The chapter “The Forest Again” absolutely destroyed me this time around and I don’t wanna talk about it, bye — Harry being reconciled with his parents, Sirius and Lupin is just too fucking much to handle (“We are so proud of you.” - I fucking cry!) — “You’ll stay with me?” “Until the very end,” said James. <333 — Harry thinking of Ginny the moment he died — Voldemort was unable to kill Harry because he used Harry’s blood to revive himself!— “Do not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all, those who live without love.” <3 — “He’s dead.” - Narcissa really came thruuuuu (motherly love, you guys) — Minnie screaming upon seeing Harry’s lifeless form <3 — the centaurs finally coming thru (after Hagrid yelled at them in the forest, carrying the dead Harry) — My proudest moment was probably seeing Kreacher leading the house elves on! SUCH A QUEEN! — “NOT MY DAUGHTER, YOU BITCH!” <3 — Harry sacrificing himself for all of the people fighting at Hogwarts put the protection on them just like Lily did for Harry; the Death Eaters couldn’t hurt them no more… I love magic! — Harry calling Voldy Tom was straight up savage — after defeating Voldy, Harry just wanted to be with Ron and Hermione - I love my wholesome trio — My favorite moment: Harry going to the Headmaster’s office and all of the portraits applauding him, I cry every fucking time! — Harry reparing his old wand with the Elder Wand! — “Nineteen Years Later” is by far not my favorite chapter but I still find little moments in there that I highly enjoy, like Draco and Harry acknowledging one another, Ron saying “If you’re not in Gryffindor, we’ll disinherit you.” as a joke, and Ron telling Rose “Don’t get too friendly with him (Scorpius), though, Rosie. Granddad Weasley would never forgive you if you married a pure-blood.”, “Don’t forgive to give Nevill our love.” “Mum! I can’t give a Professor love!”— but my favorite moment from the chapter is probably Harry reminding Al that Hagrid has invited him for tea next Friday, THIS IS SO PURE (also, how old is Hagrid? WTF) :D — “All was well.”"When I'm 80 years old and sitting in my rocking chair, I'll be reading Harry Potter," the quote card says. "And my family will say to me, 'After all this time?' And I will say, ‘Always.'"

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: 3.5 StarsGenerally, I'm not a big fan of continuous-storyline series, and the Harry Potter series is a good example of why. I'm too much of a completionist, too OCD for this shit. Even though I rated most of these books below three stars, I felt compelled to finish them because I started them. Even after it took me six months to read GOBLET OF FIRE, I pressed forward. Even though I one-starred ORDER OF THE PHOENIX, I continued on. I had to know why people love these books as much as they do. At least I got my answer.J.K. Rowling did one major thing right with this series. Her writing matured along with her readers. As Potter got older and wiser, so did Rowling's style. This helped her quite a bit because the first three novels are horribly formulaic. But how many middle-grade kids are going to dissect overused plot points and cliched story structure? Not many. And by the time her audience was old enough to start questioning the borrowed ideas and storylines, Rowling had already established her characters and readied her pawns for battle. Had the series maintained the goofy middle-grade tone throughout, it would have likely failed. Had the first three books been as dark as the final four, the series wouldn't have seen half the success it did. In the end, it became a phenomenon because it spoke to the proper age groups at the proper times.I give this series a lot of grief, but not even my cynical ass can ignore Rowling's accomplishments. After writing this series, she went from homeless mother to one of the richest people on the face of the planet. Good for her. But I think her greatest success was getting kids reading again. And while I do not fan flail over these books, I do understand the draw. I understand the nostalgia and fond memories they invoke in their readers. THE DEATHLY HALLOWS was a little heavy in the middle. Its belly meandered and dragged some, but I was never bored to the point I was with PHOENIX. Then again, I think a lot of what I enjoyed about this book stemmed from the knowledge that I was reading the last one in the series. That thought alone made me smile and was a big reason I didn't want to put the book down.I'm glad Neville got his time in the sun, but Snape's story arc was my favorite of the bunch. Luna was another one I liked. Harry didn't really shine for me until book six, and I fucking loathed everything about Ron. I wanted Hermione and Draco to end up together, as they seemed hellbent for each other, but maybe that was just me reading too much into their hatred of one another. I kept expecting Harry to catch them rage fucking in a closet between classes.Finally, I'm pretty sure Peeves and Trelawney were screwing each other every time they were able. Next time you reread this, see if you can catch why I say that. The scene I remember the best out of the entire series is the underwater stuff in GOBLET. In summation: Six easy reads and one big pile of shit equal a series that owes a lot to young readers and nostalgia. Books six and seven are clearly the best of the bunch. If I had to rate the series as a whole, I'd have to give it three stars. Final Judgment: Done at last. Done at last. Thank Tom Cruise almighty I'm done at last!A rundown of my ratings for each book:The Sorcerer's Stone ***The Chamber of Secrets ***The Prisoner of Azkaban **The Goblet of Fire **** (Wow... I don't remember liking this one enough to give it 4 stars... Odd.)The Order of the Phoenix * (I want to give this book zero stars, or, preferably, a minus 3)The Half-Blood Prince ****The Deathly Hallows ***1/2

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: I won't get this right because I'm in two places at once. I'm finished and yet I'm starting. I feel as though I have returned from a great journey. A journey that’s only begun. I finished the last book this morning and yet I feel I don’t know the whole story yet. I know there are people who make a hobby, an obsession, maybe even a career about Harry Potter lore and now I can understand why. This is not a story, it’s an experience. This is the masterpiece of a truly gifted author who understands what it means to be a great storyteller. Rowling understands that it’s not enough to throw action and plot at a reader, but to draw them, gently and unobtrusively, into a new, believable world. Her world doesn’t play by the rules of ours, but no matter. From the first chapter of book one, we are taken under Rowling’s cloak of invisibility as an ordinary human and she doesn’t insult our intelligence nor write down to us. She gains our trust, word by word, tale by tale. She gives us rich background, complex characters, deep emotion. At every page, we find something we relate to—whether an action or a feeling. Until we are under the spell and our trust in her is absolute. Like Dumbledore’s Army follows Harry, we are willing to follow wherever Rowling leads. Because we believe in her world.There are things I don’t fully understand. Things I want to explore further. And this is why the ending is only the beginning. It’s like reaching the last level of a difficult video game, winning the prize, and now the game is open for “free play.” You can go explore to your heart’s content without peril.And I will.After all this time.Always.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: I cannot describe the emotional state I'm in right now. These books are such a beautiful work of art and I'll be forever thankful to Jo for writing them. This reread killed me in the best and worst way possible. I loved the books the first time I read them but for some reason they hit me even more this time. I'm not gonna say anything except that I love Harry Potter and I'll never stop loving this series. I wish I could form some more articulate thoughts and sentences, but it's just impossible in this moment. Just...thank you Jo. Thank you for Hogwarts, which will always be my home. Thank you for Harry, Ron and Hermione, whom I loved as if they were my own friends. Thank you for all the other amazing characters you created. Thank you for the wizarding world and the magic that made us dream and escape from reality. Just thank you. I'm forever grateful.Update: it's been a whole day and I'm still sobbing. Give me more HP, this girl needs more books.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: I closed this book and finished my reread last night at about midnight. My heart was heavy and I've been in a bit of a funk ever since. What am I going to do now? I've been going to Hogwarts, fighting off dementors, meeting up with my friends from the DA, and knocking about with Harry, Ron and Hermione for the past 3 1/2 months!! And now....? I have no more Harry Potter books to read. Even though I had several other books I should have been reading, Harry won me over, and my brain couldn't focus on anything else unless I gave in and just picked up whatever HP book I was reading. I'm so thankful that J K Rowling has decided to continue with this world and we have 3 more movies of Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them and a play about Harry's youngest son. Whew. Maybe I'll be out of my funk by then.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: The last of the Harry Potter books, and the ultimate showdown between Harry and Voldemort. I admit, I love the different tone to this book compared to the previous novels. Harry and co. are very isolated for a lot of the novel, only returning to their beloved Hogwarts at the end. With the new Fantastic Bewst novels, Dumbledores backstory also finds a new interesting spin. I do find that the search for the Horcruxes is a little bit too easy, but I can overlook this for the wonderful way the series is concluded.Returning to these books has felt a little like revisiting an old friend. There's something so deliciously comforting about these characters, that they never fail to envelope me in warmth.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: I was stunned and dismayed by the time I finished this book. I have been a fan of the HP series since about 2000, when a friend recommended Book 1 to me as a cute little book that she was tutoring 5th graders with. I read it, liked it, and figured I'd pick up the next book when it came out.As each book came out, many critics and fans commented that JK had a unique style of approaching her series; the way that her books grew with her targeted audience. The series became darker and more complex, the writing more intense as the series continued.By the 5th book, I was well and truly hooked, and read each book voraciously when it came out. I re-read the entire available series just before the next book was released, and enjoyed them immensely.When Book 7 came out, I was disappointed, but only in the way that a fan is when what they have enjoyed so long is at an end. There would be no more HP books to look forward to. As I had not been part of HP online communities, nor did I enjoy the movies, this was the end of the series for me.Then I read the book, and I was furious. Six books she spent preaching about house unity, and how Hogwarts must unite or fall. Six books she spent warning of a terrible and devastating war that Harry would be in the thick of. Six books that were well enough written between plot and description that I could overlook her lack of characterization for antagonists or the fact that Ginny was essentially a flat character. And then book 7, where she completely ignores everything she spent 6 books setting up, skips around the reality of war by having Harry wander around lost on the moors for a bit, and then pulls a religious analogy out of her hat. Although the religious analogy did make me laugh -- I can't help but wonder if all those who said HP was the devil's work will be praising it like it's Narnia in 10 years.Still, I couldn't believe what she'd done to her work. I don't know if that honestly was her vision from the beginning, as she claims -- if it was, then the entire series suffers for it, and her vision is severely limited. The other alternative is that she sold out or simply didn't care because she's already richer than a queen. Whatever the reasoning, it was an awful, disappointing end to a beautifully textured series.---EDITED TO ADD---I still dislike book 7, although I love the rest of the series. I love how JK structured the books, right? I mean, she's a genius with the foreshadowing and with dropping in information about the characters backgrounds without being heavy handed. She's just a brilliant writer who structured these very rich, well-crafted worlds that hold up to multiple re-readings. I love how the books "grow" with the reader, with the first books being written for a younger reader and the later books being written for an older reader. Most of all, I love how she foreshadows across the books, so things that happen in, say, Book 5 are foreshadowed in Books 1 and 2. It's AMAZING. She's so incredibly talented, and it makes reading her books a real treat. Which was why I am still so incredibly upset at reading book 7. See, in Book 7, she brings up this whole notion of those three items (the Elder Wand, Invisibility Cloak, and Philosophers Stone) being tied together by the myth of the three brothers. That's the part that pissed me off. It felt ... cobbled in. Pulled out of a hat, last minute. Like, JK had told us about the numberless clock in the Weasley's house warning us about danger, about hunting for garden gnomes, about the time Ron's teddy bear got turned into a spider ... but she didn't mention this apparently incredibly common wizarding childrens story? She talks about all these daily aspects of wizarding life on a regular basis, introduced through Ron's family, but never once -- never once in 6 entire books does Ron or Ginny or anyone even let out a breath of a whisper about this apparently common wizarding fable? Think about how often you reference common fairy stories and fables in your life. Cinderella, Red Riding Hood, Big Bad Wold, etc. So if JK Rowling actually had this idea of a wizarding fable/myth as a major plot in her overarching series, I think she would have woven it in as foreshadowing much more effectively. What I think happened is this:Right around the time Book 7 was being written, all these internet/ social media/ fanboard sites were really taking off. They weren't huge before then, but they were really taking off as she'd released Books 5 & 6 and was writing book 7. I think that the fans had pretty much figured out what was happening, plot wise -- which is a mark of what a great writer JK Rowling is -- and JK felt bad about that -- which is a natural creative response.I think her publisher advised her to keep quiet about reading the fanboards for legal reasons, which she wisely did, but I fully believe she read them, and that she wasn't happy about two things:(1) The proliferation of fanfic and noncanon fanfic pairings(2) How thoroughly the fans had guessed the key points of the plot (particularly what would be happening with Snape and Dumbledore and the Horcruxes).So I think that JK just sort of pulled that bit about the 3 Wizarding brothers and the ancient fairy tale and 3 legendary items out of her hat (with no foreshadowing regarding this plotline in the previous 6 books) because she wanted to surprise her fans with a sort of "gotcha"/ surprise moment. Furthermore, I suspect she wrote in the epilogue as a sort of middle finger to the proliferation of fanfic writers, as though to say, "And by the way, no. That is not how it happens. Harry and Hermoine do not end up together. Harry and Draco do not end up together. Ron and Pansy do not end up together. These people end up together, in these pairs. I do so decree it, and thus it shall be."So that's why I don't like Book: 7. I feel like it's less true to the ethos of the series than the rest of the books. I feel like JK Rowling kind of strayed from herself as a writer ... that she reacted (poorly) to her fans, and that it reflects badly on her work. I can't really enjoy reading the book even now. It feels out of step with the rest of the series.I've mostly moved on. I've forgiven her (even if the insult is imagined). She's a truly talented writer and generous and compassionate woman. She's an inspiration to me, as a writer. And it was a weird time in fandom and for the internet, when that book was being written. Everyone makes mistakes. I think JK has more than made up for the upset of book 7, though -- she wrote 6 other amazing books, she's gracious and considerate in the fandom community, and she's a principled and compassionate woman. A true role model. What's one book in comparison to the rest of her legacy?

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: The perfect ending to a perfect series. Not sure how I should write this review as not only is J.K. Rowling problematic at the moment, but everything seemed to be said. The Deathly Hallows started slow, really slow, which might've lacked my 5-star rating. The first half or quarter of the book, I found my self a bit bored/irritated of the trio apparating, disapparting and complaining that they don't have a plan. However, once Rowling got a grip of the plot and established grounds, the book soars high and nails it with a bang in this epic finale. The Harry Potter series will always and forever remain my favorite series of all time, and the characters will forever live unto my soul. Thank you, J.K. Rowling, for creating a world full of magic, love and joy, and a place called Hogwarts where I wholeheartedly name it my second home. My favorites in the series are definitely the Prisoner of Azkaban and the Half-Blood Prince. However, there wasn't a single instalment that I disliked or merely found to be average. I absolutely loved and devoured each and very instalment in this series, and they're all perfect in their own way. I will forever cherish this series that marked a special place in my heart which will forever remain in generations to come.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text:
“Do not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all those who live without love.”
I want to make this final review about 
Neville Longbottom
Let me explain why. A couple of years ago, I had a very disturbing conversation with a Potterhead friend.Crazy friend of mine: "Did you know that Neville Longbottom was actually the real hero in Harry Potter's book?"Me: "WTF ?! O_o"This sounding more and more crazy friend of mine: "Yes, I read a theory that says that JK Rowling wrote this book to make us think that Harry was the hero, but in the end, you realize that it has been Neville all along"After laughing at him and calling him crazy I went back to my business. But this idea stayed in my head for several days. I called all my Harry Potter's fan friends in the middle of the night and they all told me that this was nonsense and that I should go back to sleep.But this wasn't enough to get this theory out of my head, therefore, I decided back then to do a Potter-movies-athlon (I always need a good excuse). And I started to understand what he meant. Then I re-read all the books and I thought I needed the Internet to help me understand better.I found an awesome article online which made me realize that might be right (you can check it here if you want), but basically it all starts with Sybill Trelawney's first prophecy that you can find below: 
"The one with the power to vanquish the Dark Lord approaches... born to those who have thrice defied him, born as the seventh month dies... and the Dark Lord will mark him as his equal, but he will have power the Dark Lord knows not... and either must die at the hand of the other for neither can live while the other survives... the one with the power to vanquish the Dark Lord will be born as the seventh month dies..."
During the prophecy, Trelawney specified that the requirements for the boy of the prophecy who was capable of (but not necessary would) defeating the Dark Lord are the followings:- Male,- Born in the closing days of July of 1980,- His parents had defied Voldemort three times and lived to tell about it,- He would have a power that Voldemort was unable or unwilling to comprehend.And of course, the book being called Harry Potter, and him meeting all the requirements, we all assumed it refers to our Harry, but Neville Longbottom also meets all the requirements: he was born on July, 30th 1980, his parents Frank and Alice Longbottoms, are Aurors who had directly defied Voldemort on three separate occasions. However, on the contrary of James and Lilly Potter, Neville parent's are still alive, they were tortured into insanity with the Cruciatus Curse by a group of Death Eaters and were placed at St Mungo's Hospital for Magical Maladies and Injuries.Moreover, Neville proved himself by standing up to Voldemort and destroying his last Horcrux, Nagini. Harry couldn't have defeated Voldemort without Neville's action in the first place.
“We’re all going to keep fighting, Harry. You know that?”
The second point that we can make us think that Neville is the true hero is the following idea, based on the fact that Harry Potter's generation is modelled on James Potter's. You can see it follows the same pattern with the following points:- Harry is like James, a leader of the group- Ron is like Sirus, a faithful friend- Hermione like Remus is really smart, a little bit outcast at first but then fully part of the group- And then Neville is Peter Pettigrew. Everyone is making fun of him. Clumsy and chubby.(- According to that theory, Ginny Weasley is Lilly Potter)But this is where the story change. Neville is loyal to Harry where Peter has been a coward. He stands by Harry no matter what, even when Voldemort asked him to join his side. This theory says that JKR wanted to show that only one "side character" changes the whole story. Instead of darkness and terror, Neville is the one who kills the last Horcrux (Nagini) and allowing Harry to defeat Voldemort. Instead of joining him and betraying his friends, instead of choosing the easy path, life above all moral, he chooses to be faithful.
“It takes a great deal of bravery to stand up to our enemies, but just as much to stand up to our friends.”
Just think about it, if Neville would have acted as Peter did, the ending would have been probably the opposite.We clearly see how his character grows during those 7 books/8 films. I personally find this theory very convincing, I'm eager to read your opinion on it!

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: --Yes, I’m aware of the “read another book” “Anti-Harry Potter Action” response to cringe liberal tweets. --Yes, I’ve read other books.--Yes, Voldemort Trump and #resistance Dumbledore’s Army are cringe.--Yes, J.K. Rowling’s opinions can be worse than cringe. --Yes, I grew up reading Harry Potter and also listened to Jim Dale's narrations in the background. --Yes, I’ve probably gone through the series a million times. --Yes, nostalgia. --Yes, it's my favorite children’s series (Pullman’s His Dark Materials is also excellent but it’s a trilogy with a linear plot). --Yes, this finale has 2 of my favorite chapters (“The Prince’s Tale” and “King’s Cross”)--Yes, I still find the series well-crafted and enchanting. --No, I do not understand how the Weasley twins owned the Marauder’s Map yet somehow never noticed some bloke named Peter Pettigrew was sleeping in Ron’s bed at Hogwarts for over 2 school years.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: And so I've come to the end of this marvelous series. I am sad to say goodbye to Harry, Hermione, Ron and all of their friends and fellow wizards, but I am so grateful to J.K. Rowling for creating such a magnificent world. It's a testament to how good this series is that I read all seven books in basically a month. I listened to the audiobooks, which feature a tremendous performance by Jim Dale. Several times the story moved me to tears, and countless other times Jim made me laugh and smile. Because this is Goodreads, you've probably read all the books already, but if you want to enjoy them again, I highly recommend the audiobooks.Favorite Quotes"Do not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all those who live without love.""We're all human, aren't we? Every human life is worth the same, and worth saving.""It is a curious thing, Harry, but perhaps those who are best suited to power are those who have never sought it. Those who, like you, have leadership thrust upon them, and take up the mantle because they must, and find to their own surprise that they wear it well."

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: I have finished my 2017 Harry Potter reread!This review contains unmarked spoilersAs the other 6 reviews I have done for this series this review will also be all over the place. Because so much happens in this book I think I will shorten the review by only talking about the things I really want to talk about and keeping it kind of short. First off the Dursley's are going into hiding. I sometimes wonder if Mr. Dursley has any sense because he says we are leaving then nope we aren't. Dudley was like screw it dad I want to leave. Petunia just wants Dudley to be safe and at the end they did leave Private Drive. Dudley's last words to Harry was I didn't think you were a waste of space or something along those lines. I keep forgetting that. Harry leaves Private Drive with the Order and of course they had a master plan that they would turn 6 people into Harry as they escaped into safe houses. Each one different. Harry rode with Hagrid which is very emotional because Hagrid is the one to bring Harry there and he is the one taking him away. The twins, Ron, Hermione, Fluer, and Mundungus turn into Harry and they are off into the night to the different safe houses. Apparently the Death Eaters knew that they were traveling that night which we later learned how and why they knew. Hedwig dies which is extremely sad and Hagrid fell from the sky trying to protect Harry. The first time I read it I though Hagrid was dead but he is alive and well and I am glad Hagrid is okay. They arrive at Tonk's house and then take a porkey to the Burrow. Bill and Fluer's wedding take place in the Burrow and during the wedding the Death Eaters took over the ministry. Hermione disapperates with Ron and Harry into the city where they are met by Death Eaters. I don't think it was ever com firmed whether or not Harry still had the trace on him. They spent the night in Grimmauld place and later learned Kreacher's story. We figure out that R.A.B is Regulus Black and he allowed Voldemort to use Kreacher to drink the potion to hide his Horcrux. Regulas of course with the help of Kreacher goes to the cave and drinks the potion and tells Kreacher to destroy it before dying. It was honestly a heartbreaking moment. Regulus unlike Sirius treated Kreacher with more respect and Kreacher does love Regulus more. Harry gives Kreacher the fake Horcrux and Kreacher looses it and after that treats Harry, Ron, and Hermione more kindly. He also find Mundungus and they discover that he sold the locket to Umbridge. I am pretty sure when everyone read that part for the first time they are all, including me, this lady again? I thought she was gone. With careful planning and with the help of polyjuice potion the three of them manage to get into the ministry and find the locket but like Kreacher, could not destroy it. Later on Ron will stab it with the word of Gryffindor. Speaking of the sword, Neville proves himself as a worthy Griffindor as he mamages to pull the sword out of the hat just like Harry. Neville I feel like thought he didn't belong in this hout but he proved he is brave and courageous. Not being able to return to Sirius's house they start camping out in the woods, Ron leaves but comes back Harry ignore's Ron's warning and says Voldemort's name and they get captured. Hermione is tortured and honestly that scene was very scary because Bellatrix is cruel and I didn't know the first time I read it whether or not Hermione survived. She does and recovers in shell cottage where Bill and Fluer now live. Dobby rescues the trio plus a few others including Luna and Dobby dies in the process. It is a sad moment and even Harry is so devastated that he had trouble saying anything but Goodbye at Dobby's funeral. Way before that when the met Bathilda and learned she was actually a snake Hermione breaks Harry's wand. Harry feels like a part of him is missing. Told by Ollivander his wand is repairable he later tries to fix it with the elder wand and it works. At shell cottage they made an agreement with Griphook the goblin and pulled off an epic break in into Gringotts. I loved that part and it was my favourite moment in this book. The battle of Hogwarts was more sad and more epic this time I read it. Grawp threw Hagrid through the window so he could join the fight. I really wished we could of seen that scene in the movie. Percy comes back and learns his lesson that family is very important and he witnessed his brother die. Honestly it was heartbreaking to see Percy, who finally wanted to see and hep his family again only to lose one of them. I mean I cried reading that part too.Lets not forget at the end that the house elves lead by Kreacher also helped fight. And Mrs. Weasley fighting Bellatrix was insane. Bellatrix almost killed Ginny and Mrs. Weasley was mad. I don't think I ever saw her that mad ever. People tried to help her but she reused any help and they all stared to watch. I feel like everyone stopped fighting or were half fighting but watching them fight.That's it for now and I probably add more later because I still have a lot to say.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: Harry Potter is Harry Potter, but I struggled to like this final book for several reasons. They're the same things that bothered me the first time I read it, but the final confrontation and brilliant revelations and reversals of certain characters wiped them from my memory back then. Now the second time, I find that these reasons linger. 1. So many deaths. Right from the beginning, starting with (view spoiler)[Hedwig (hide spoiler)]. Somehow that really got to me this time!2. So much speculation about Dumbledore and his true motivations and shortcomings. I do like how this was resolved in the end, but didn't enjoy the maligning of Dumbledore, or Harry's doubts about him.3. So much time spent with only Harry, Ron and Hermione running around the forest. I miss their interactions with other characters and the wizarding world.4. No Hogwarts until 75%. This is kind of the same as the previous point except that Hogwarts simply deserves its own line. I've realized that the setting is a huge part of my enjoyment of this series, and I was impatient with the book until the story returned there. I missed all of the extra characters - teachers, ghosts, portrait-dwellers, fellow students - as well as the magic of the castle itself.I still love the series. There's nothing else like it. It's darker than I would have liked, even knowing where it was going the second time around, but like I said, I just wanted to live at Hogwarts and not watch the whole world being destroyed, along with so many people that Harry could possibly consider family. The ending is really great. It's one of those endings that is actually epic, and some of the minor characters have great moments in the battle at Hogwarts. But I found this finale bitter enough that I might avoid any future re-reads and stick to the earlier books for the nostalgia of simply hanging out at Hogwarts.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: I will never find the perfect words to describe how I feel about the Harry Potter series. It's an incredible story, everybody knows that.I am not unique in my connection with these books. When I was younger, I would wait with excited anticipation for the next HP book to come out. When it did, I would hole myself up in my room and devour it in a day. I had read other books that I'd liked well enough prior to HP, but this was different. It was that feverish feeling you get when you're so wrapped up in a story. It's the absolute love you have for the characters, and the spectacular world-building that stretches your imagination. It cemented my love for reading.Twelve years later, I re-read the series, finishing with this last installment. This time, I read it slower. I wanted to savor every bit of it. And it was exactly as good as I remembered.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: I've just finished rereading this for the fourth or fifth time, eight years after its release. Still, I found myself an absolute teary mess during chapter 34 - 'The Forest Again'. Coincidentally, Rowling has stated this is her own favourite chapter. The Prince's Tale and the deaths of Fred and Lupin still make my eyes water, but nothing compares to those scenes in the forest. Rowling deserves every little bit of her success. This is a fantastic conclusion to an unbelievable story. She is a true rarity; a fantastic author and an even better storyteller.  “Do not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all, those who live without love.”

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: 05/01/18A completely mind blowing work of literature. How I went my whole life without reading these, I will never know.07/21/18Don't mind me updating my thoughts 2.5 months later, I just really think I need to get out more than just one sentence to sum up how I feel about something I have thought about literally every single day since I last picked it up. There will be a lot of spoilers in this, just as a warning.Anyways, reading these was an absolute adventure from start to finish—I can’t see any other series giving me the same emotions that this one has. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows was, again, a really good one hence the 5 stars.I don't know if it's because I was late to the party that I feel like it's overlooked, but I really wanted to know how Aunt Petunia felt when she was saying goodbye to Harry... I was so looking forward to that loving embrace he lacked all those years! But honestly I liked how it packed that punch right at the beginning; I wasn't expecting something like that to happen so soon. I'm also happy that Dudley was at least a little bit concerned for Harry when he realized he would probably never see him again. It doesn't excuse how awful he was to him, but at least he had some sort of empathy at the end.Admittedly, for the first three-quarters I was (for lack of a better word) bored? Experiencing Harry, Ron, and Hermione venture off to find the Horcruxes was fun but I really missed the Hogwarts setting and I was becoming quite restless with none of the questions I had being answered yet. Then, after they visited the Malfoy Manor with about 200 pages to go, I really got more into it and read that last bit in a day. Dobby’s death I knew about already or else I think that would have shocked me but Fred’s death I didn’t know about and that had me so sad, I cried my eyes out. Literally a good seven pages before that, Ron and Hermione kissed and I was so happy because I had wanted them together for SOSOSO LONG, but then Fred happened at the end of that chapter and I was really saddened. I had to put the book down in order to soak in that all of that really just happened within such a short time. I think by then, it was actually starting to set in that this was ending for real and I was really scared to see who else would die.Now, for the whole Snape storyline: knowing the truth about Snape, I am really sad that he died. And that whole white doe thing?! My mouth actually dropped because I was sure that was Dumbledore’s patronus. However, I don’t think that makes up for everything he did to Harry throughout the years at Hogwarts. I almost can’t believe he was loyal to Dumbledore the whole time because of all the negative things he did in the other books. I know people really love Snape by the end, but my feelings didn't really change all that much. I mean, he bullied Neville to the point of being Neville's boggart, completely embarrassed and ridiculed Hermione in front of other students when Malfoy's Densaugeo spell hit her, and don't get me started on what was supposedly love for Lily. Snape's hatred for James was stronger than his love for Lily, and it caused him to be obsessed with having her. If you really love someone, and I mean genuinely love and care about them, I would hope you would treat their orphaned son a little bit better than Snape treated Harry. Yeah, what he did was great and all but all those things he did to him and others in 6 other books aren't justified to me just because of that. Honestly, thinking about it again makes me angry all over so I will stop while I'm ahead. Nonetheless, I do still think one of my favourite parts was when Harry looked into the pensive at Snape’s memories and found everything out; it had me reading so fast to know what had happened.Moving forward, I'm not sure if I would read Harry Potter & the Cursed Child because a) I don't know if the whole "read like a play" thing is for me; and b) I have heard mixed reviews, most of them not being good ones. Also, I felt like this was a good way to end it off and the epilogue was enough for me. Here's to being totally ruined by a series for the first time, I'm excited at the thought of experiencing more pain and heartache like this over a series in the future (although I highly doubt any of them could affect me as much as this one did)!!¡!

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: 5 Stars.... DUH!The last book in my re-read and it’s a sad ending – I will definitely be re-re-reading these how can you not! Oh THIS BOOK! Dudley at the start of this book is everything and it gives me hope that he won’t just turn into his father after all what an emotional and tear-jerking moment! J K Rowling really knows how to get you in the feels. HEDWIGGGGGGGGG! Honestly my heart can’t take this book! There is so much action in this book you just can’t stop reading – I remember reading this the first time and being made to go bed because I just couldn’t stop and I have the exact same reaction on this read - I will never stop re-reading this book. The romance really build in this book too Ginny and Harry and Ron and Hermione I means it’s about time! I think if you haven’t read the books and have only watched the films you are really missing out! The books manage to go much more in depth not only characters but also the whole plot. Creature is one of those characters that is let down in the films and the books really go into the house elves and the way they are mistreated – and why Creature is the way he is. This book has EVERYONE in all the characters really get a mention throughout this book and I love it, it really shows us the progression of the series and you really feel like you know each character personally by this point which makes this book so much more heart-felt and heart-breaking. Voldemort is also much more sinister in the books and you get more detail of exactly what his ‘perfect wizarding world’ is! I wish the conversation between Lupin and Harry had happen in the films too! If they did an extended version of the films that were on for 4hours each I would happily watch!!!!! More details about Dumbledore also emerge in this book – but I really wish J K Rowling would bring out a book just for Dumbledore’s life! The last instalment of the Harry Potter series really is ACTION, ACTION and more ACTION! Bathilda’s Street is one of my favourite chapters. There are really so many amazing chapters in this book I just can’t get enough of it! The Tale of the Three Brother is a little story in a story and it’s EVERYTHING! Ron’s fears are so sad and beautiful! So true to real life and I really felt for Ron throughout these books and even more so in this one! Always 2nd best within his family and his friendships! Kingsley’s patronus being a Lynx I mean can he be any cooler?!I am so sad that this is OVER and I will have to re-read these again! I will never be bored of these and they will never get old! I will have to read something easy next as this never gets easier! SNAPE! (That’s all I have to say) if you know you know! (CRIES) I could go on and on about this book but it’s really the last few chapters that are the most heart-breaking and the most joyful this really is an amazing series and I would suggest everyone should read it at least once – some of the earlier books are harder to read yes – but I swear its SOOO WORTH IT!

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows

5 stars

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: The final Book (7) in the Harry Potter series and I must admit I'm a little sad the magical adventure is over, I will also admit I will definitely be having a re-read of this series, it was emotional, fun and exciting.There were plenty of laugh out loud moments and times when I found myself wiping away the odd tear.And JK Rowling's I felt in this book just went on a fully blown killing spree...my goodness.I just love how the characters grow on you throughout this series.. even Snape you can't help but love and hate him,But there are plenty with NO love lost there at all!!!!!!Each adventure in this series gets better with every book and the constant battle between Harry and Voldemort's hate relationship gets darker throughout and you can forget poor Harry and his gang are only young teenagers.It's definitely a series I would recommend and who cares how old you are I think almost everyone can enjoy it 🧙📖

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: Harry has to first find, and then destroy Voldemort's power base, the remaining Horcuxes. As the world and his allies fall around him, he has never being under so much pressure, Harry and co. are really up against it in this grand finale, but when the time comes he hopes is friends, allies and mentor will stand firm.This final instalment, begins with a bang, muddles along and then the final 400 pages are delightfu; whirlwind of high drama that completes this amazingly successful and era defining series. Great read, a great finale! 8 out of 12.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: “There are far far worse things in the living world than dying”“Tell me one last thing,” said Harry. “ is this real? Or has this been happening inside my head?”“Of course it is happening inside your head, Harry, but why on earth should that mean that it is not real?”“After all this time?” “Always”I think those three quotes, sum up the whole 7 books and mostly this book, it’s been long since I’ve been enraptured by a book and it’s with a bittersweet feeling that I have ended reading.Hats off to Miss Rowling and an apology to my best friend for being so late in joining Dumbledore’s Army.P.S. Alan Rickman, you are the bravest wizard I know.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: What an amazing finale to this wonderful series. This book was both heartwarming and painful. I cried so much, a lot of things that happened in this book were excruciating but still, it had so many sweet moments that helped dull the pain. Harry's journey has finally ended and I felt so proud of him and his choices. This story will live with me forever. I must say that Snape and Lily's relationship has broken my heart a little. I know Snape made some bad choices but I truly wish he had a better life than this, he deserved to be loved and cared for. I fully intend to read this beautiful series soon ❤️.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: Well, I've finished the Harry Potter series, and it's the first time for me. I say first time because most people have read and reread them several times. Maybe I will too, I don't know. Of course I've known for years how the story ends, what with the movies, family, etc. But this final book was special, a fitting end to the story. Five stars, and overall I give the series five stars as well. They all weren't perfect, but like a mosaic, they fit together to form a masterpiece, a phenomenon that will endure for decades, maybe centuries.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: Ugly tears and the most epic conclusion to a series ever. I am so sad that my this rereading session is over. How lucky I am, that I got to experience growing up along the publication of these books (well at least with the later books). book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: A great ending to a fantastic series. It was really great to go through this series again after so long. Watching the movies just isn't the same as reading the book. I love the details that you get from the books. Don't get me wrong, I did enjoy the movies, but the books are just superior to what they could put in the movies. Now I feel like I have to leave a bunch of close friends behind and others I have buried.This is such a roller coaster. The journey to get to the end is long and full of mysteries that must be solved. Characters that I loved are lost and characters that I despise are brought to a new light. Even though I knew how it would end up having read and watched previously, it didn't take away the hatred felt or the sadness that was to come.There is one thing I wish had some more finality to it and that is Umbridge. Oh, how I despise that woman and wish she would have met some sort of end that I could have relished in. That is the one character that I felt I needed more closure for. I don't often despise a character like I have her.So many losses it makes me sad. The list is like a list of friends and it is heartbreaking; each one as they come. I can see their faces and the tears stream down. I think of the death eaters and I just can't understand them; so much hatred. How can they want to be someones pawn and how can someone be full of so much hate. I guess that is a good thing that I can't understand them. That would be like being able to understand a killer out in the world today. To kill without feeling; I don't want to ever understand that. Then I look on the other side and see the friendships, the families, the love and I love that. I love to see friends coming together to help one another; to sacrifice themselves for the ones they love and to fight for the greater good. It was great to have Percy come back to the family that loves him and to admit he was wrong and selfish. Oh how I love these characters and this story. It took so much to come to the ending and to make everything right. I have always felt that the ending was just so complicated, but the story as a whole is great. I think there is just so much twisted into the Harry and Voldemort history that it makes it confused and diluted. It is definitely not simple, but in the end brings everything back to complete the circle and make everything whole. I love books that have great character development. This entire series does this for me and I believe that is the main reason why I think so highly of them. I become entirely attached to the characters and I am willing them forward on their quests or the friendships or their romances. I feel loss and cry when they pass or I loathe them something fierce and can feel the anger well up inside me. Nothing is better than great characters to make a story whole and to give it feeling. This is such a great series and I would have to say even better then second time around.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: At the beginning of August, I finally finished my read-through of the Harry Potter series. I started this project last summer and it felt great to finish this month. The final book in the series did not disappoint me and I couldn’t put it down for the last two hundred pages. Now that I’m done, I’m ready for all of the Harry Potter references in pop culture- I’ll finally know what they mean! I’ve been watching the movies as I finish each book and the only one I have left is Deathly Hallows: Part 2.I put off reading the series for so long because I thought I’d missed my window. People have been in love with Harry Potter for decades and I thought it was too late for me to join the club. You know what? That kind of thinking was so off base. It’s never too late to pick up a good book. I completely understand why Harry Potter is special to so many people around the world and now it’s special for me too. This was the first time I’ve read through the series, but it won’t be the last.//What an ending! I'm so happy that I've finally read the series from beginning to end. Now people can hit me with all their Harry Potter references! ;)

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: I could try and write something eloquent and magnificent and give people the impression that I can separate myself and my emotions when writing the review for this book. 'Try' being the operative word. I love these books. Chamber of Secrets was the first chapter book I had ever read. (I was four and I saw the first movie in the theater so @ me)I remember the first time I read this. I was in the 3rd grade, in Catholic school. I had class the next morning but my mom let me stay home and read the book after she surprised me that morning with a copy. I remember she kept having to check in on me because I didn't leave my bed. I read this book in one sitting. It took me 12 hours. Characters that could've had AMAZING DEVELOPMENTAL ARCS BUT DIDN'T:~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~I'm an emotional wreck.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: April 2020 If there is anything that we can take from Harry Potter - it's that hope, faith and courage can get us as far as it gets, but Love lasts for an eternity.  January 2016 The perfect book to kickstart 2016 has ended and now, I don't know what to do with my life.Yes, I still get sad over several deaths. YES, I had ‘em coming but it still manage to give me a pang.I couldn't thank J.K.R enough for creating one of the most magical series ever. Harry Potter is not just a story, for one thing it's showed readers a few lessons that I won't ever forget. I've already said my goodbyes to Harry, Ron and Hermione before, this makes it the 5th time but it certainly won't be the last.(view spoiler)[Raising my wand to the brave souls who perished in the Battle of Hogwarts:- Professor Severus Snape- Remus Lupin & Nymphadora Tonks- Colin Creevey- Fred Weasley- Lavender Brown- All the other unnamed Hogwart students who fought just as bravely.
