book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text:
Traaaaaaaash.This book is so freaking good and yet! I'm so mad!Honestly there's so much to like about this series but there is an equal amount to hate.-Harry is a jerk.-Dumbledore is a moron.-Voldemort is more bumbling bad guy than evil villain.and there are so many plot weaknesses that can only be explained away by, 'because JK said so.' which, to me, is not good enough.But also:-Snape-Weasley twins-DragonsWhat makes me the most mad about this book is that it's actually pretty freaking good. It's got some great action and mystery, surprising twists, great hero moments. But then it's absolutely 
RUINED
 by the last hundred or so pages. That rubbish ending infuriates me because it's so freaking STUPID. It's like JK was just so done with this series that she knotted all the loose ends so that they can never, ever be undone again.So let's pause the hate so I can talk about the first part of the book.Aside from some familiar frustration with Dumbledore's vagueness and secret keeping, there's a lot to like. The trio set out on the prescribed quest and it becomes quickly evident that Hermione is the true hero of the book. She saves Harry's ungrateful ass so many times and barely bats an eyelid. Whereas me, I'd be reminding him every time he pulled out that angst bullsh*t. (view spoiler)[Like, 'yo Harry, I get that you're mad that I broke your wand accidentally, but remember how I also SAVED YOUR ASS FROM A GIANT SNAKE? Just saying.'  (hide spoiler)]Ron is the most real character and I love him for sarcasm and reluctance and habit of saying exactly what everyone else is thinking (oh hey, I also just described myself. Huh). He's a stand up guy. He's also hilarious with his stinging sass. (view spoiler)[Honestly disappointed about how the romance between he and Hermione played out. They deserved more than a single passionate kiss at the end. (I did LOL when Harry yelled 'OI!' at them for it, though.) They're a far cuter couple than Harry and Ginny. (hide spoiler)]As much as I love the Weasleys, Ginny does nothing for me. I do like that she enjoys blowing things up, but totally not feeling the whole her-and-Harry thing. Bit much. Also, I still think it's a dog move to go after your best friend's sibling. After all Ron's done for you, you ungrateful twat. But I love Luna and Neville and that they continue being badass without having Harry around to hold their hands. Neville in particular has had some great (albeit sudden) character development.Lupin is one of my fave characters, so I'm kind of mad about how JK writes him in this book. He acts like a total child, and I didn't believe it. It didn't make sense to me; that happens a lot here. The kids are running around doing things adults should be doing, and meanwhile the adults are chillin', taking it easy and acting like kids with no responsibility. No one seems to take control, and JK's actually pretty vague about what everyone else is up to while Harry's running around acting important.Meanwhile, Harry's gotta find and destroy 4 horcruxes, and DAMN does this kid move slow. He takes his sweet ass time, so although there's plenty happening in the first half of the book, it doesn't really progress until about 300-odd pages in. Then it all comes tumbling out in a rush and you gotta read slowly in order to take it all in. But it's kind of fun trying to unravel exactly what the heck is going on? Like all that stuff with the hallows? What's that all about?Downside though is trying to remember the fifty thousand new characters that pop up. Also I feel like a lot of these death eaters have been taken down repeatedly? Why they no die?!I LOVE the flashbacks, though, and all the hints at life before Harry. It makes me feel so sad for James and Lily. All those 'what if?'s, man. My heart.Plus DRAGONS. I love dragons. (See my review for GoF.) Also my main man Snape has gone full dark side so that's a lot of fun. (view spoiler)[Seriously, of all the deaths in this book (and there are so. freaking. many.) that one hurts my heart the most. Those feels. I wish he'd had a more noble death, tbh. He totally deserved better. (hide spoiler)]Sooooooo here's my grudges. 
YOU ARE NOW ENTERING SPOILER TERRITORY.
(view spoiler)[-SO. MANY. DEATHS.Hedwig. Moody. Rufus. Dobby. Peter. Crabbe. Fred. Tonks. Lupin. Snape. This all after Cedric, Sirius and Dumbledore in the previous three novels. There is such a blatant disregard for the aftershocks of death that these just don't get an emotional response from me. How are we supposed to believe how broken up Harry is over Dobby when a)he got over his Sirius grief pretty fast and b)he actually grumbled a fair bit about Dobby? Also, so many people have died by this stage that it's kinda desensitising. Moody was forgotten easily, and so was Hedwig. Fred, Tonks and Lupin were STUPID POINTLESS DEATHS. Of all the hundreds of students and teachers that took part in the battle at the end, only 53 people died. How did Lupin and Tonks BOTH die? How did all the inexperienced students survive when a werewolf and an auror couldn't??? And JK doesn't even grace us with an actual cause of death, so once again lives are lost just coz JK says so. Fred died a good honest death, so I'll take his. Same with Snape, even if it was a sh*tty death: his death had meaning, and kinda made sense in terms of plot. But the rest? I just got so mad because clearly JK had no decent explanation, she just wanted these characters to die. That's brutal.-That whole, '19 years later' BULLDUST:1. Absolutely ridiculous and pointless inclusion. Just quite clearly JK saying 'yo I am never gonna write more HP books so forget it.' (Happy to milk the cash cow by churning out all this supplementary crap, though, isn't she? Yet still not giving in to fan demands for a Marauders spin-off. So disappointing.)2. These poor kids have worse names than the kids of today's celebrities. Albus Severus? YOU DIDN'T EVEN LIKE SNAPE YOU TWO-FACED SON OF A GUN. Scorpius?!! You poor bastard. AND WHY ARE THERE SO MANY OF THEM??3. Zero inclusion about any of the other characters, which was a big F.U. to the series. No proper epilogue about what happened to anyone else, just 'all the power couples grew up, got married and had ridiculously-named babies. Who then went to Hogwarts.' Oh, wait, but I guess that kinda makes sense because JK KILLED THEM ALL.  (hide spoiler)]There were a lot of character behaviours that didn't seem to match up about what we knew about the characters, so that frustrated me a fair bit, and once again Harry can do no wrong and always comes out on top, while Voldy, The Most Powerful Wizard Ever, is thwarted repeatedly. Thank god he actually offs a ton of people randomly here and there or I'd have zero respect for him as The Big Bad. Poor guy just can't catch a break.There's just so much in this book that I feel was included just because JK felt like it, not for any kind of logical purpose. For example, I've been wondering a lot about the absence of Harry's grandparents, and it turns out they were just never included because JK needed Harry to have no family. So when she was questioned about it she gave some crap about them all dying natural deaths before Harry but honestly, WHAT A LOAD. It bothers me. This is such a beautifully vivid world - it's so incredibly detailed, and colourful, and it's brilliantly done, but these little plot holes really cheapen the experience. This would probably have been a 4-star read for me without those grumbles, but they just ruined the whole series for me a bit so this scrapes by with two stars. A clever installment in the series, and a truly grand finale, absolutely spoiled by what I see as author arrogance. Some authors will talk about how some stories kinda write themselves - clearly this is not something that happens for JK. The entire ending is way too forced.So while I'm finally happy to admit that I do actually love this world, and plenty of the characters and events in it, I stand by my hatred of it's hero and this absolutely rubbish conclusion.***See my other reviews for the series here:Sorcerer's Stone (4 stars)Chamber of Secrets (2 stars)Prisoner of Azkaban (4stars)Goblet of Fire (3 stars)Order of the Phoenix (2 stars)Half-Blood Prince (3 stars)***
Original delayed review:
What a load of utter rubbish.That ending? (view spoiler)[ Why do all the powerful people die but all the students survive? That just doesn't make sense! I feel like Rowling was going more for shock factor than actual sensible storyline. And the kids at the end ... honestly, what was that sh*t? (hide spoiler)] I somehow got addicted to reading this series, and it was okay, there's loads of imagination, but I actually can't stand Rowling's writing. It's illogical. She writes more to create shock factor than to evolve characters in a logical sense. She kills people off because it will create an uproar. She did some great things with this series and created some memorable characters and moments but I just was not impressed by the writing at all. Harry Potter himself is the most detestable character I've ever read. He's a complete d*ckbag and I cannot understand how people came to love him when he's just so conceited and idiotic. He's the angsty teenager to rule all angsty teenagers.I was thankful this series ended. I am depressed that they're still churning out spinoffs and films. Can we please relegate HP to the past already?

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: Re-read Again   Re-read Again:  I return to this book almost every year. What a beautiful, timeless story. Re-read for the Holidays:  Just as magical and epic as the first time around. One of my all time favourites. Re-read: 01/08/18  I had such a wonderful time listening to this as I fell asleep. In my opinion, this book was pretty much impeccable, and I do not think JK Rowling could have ended it any other way. I know these books mean a great deal to many of us, and when I heard those 3 closing farewell words read out loud in Jam Dale’s wonderful voice, I found myself smiling the way you would at something you once loved. When I was 11, this book did not appeal to me because it diverted from what I was used to in the series. But as an adult, I appreciate the complexity and darkness of the plot so much more. While this is not my favourite book in this series, it is nonetheless an incredible read, one that I will always remember and cherish.  Previous Review  "To think that people had years and years, time to waste, so much time it dragged, and he was clinging to each second."  I just finished reading this book and oh...my...gosh... I have so many emotions flowing through me right now. What can I say about a book that leaves me speechless? Finishing the last book in the Harry Potter series was a bittersweet experience. Like many others, I grew up with these characters and they mean a lot to me. I remember finishing this book as a child and realizing that there will probably never be a book 8. And even as an adult, I reached that same epiphany. However, I'm honoured that I had the opportunity to age with these books. I do not have enough words to describe the gratitude I feel towards JK Rowling for teaching me, and many others, about compassion, friendship, bravery and unity through this book series. Closing Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows felt a bit like losing a friend. I wonder if I'll ever feel the same connection towards another book like this again? There really is something magical about the Harry Potter book series. There are several familiar elements that are missing from this book. In the previous books, we were always used to Harry going back to Hogwarts, but not anymore. I was pretty bummed because reading about Hogwarts was my favourite part of the book series. No more Potions? No more Charms? No more Defence Against the Dark Arts? No more Quidditch? In fact, for most of this book, the trio are isolated from both the Wizarding and Muggle world. However, I understand the author wants the reader to understand the sacrifices Harry is making to defeat Voldemort. Harry has come of age and is forced to accept adult responsibilities. Finishing the dangerous task Dumbledore left Harry will prove to be a dangerous and rigorous journey.  From this point forward, this review contains spoilers  Hermione once said,  "And if we can't trust Dumbledore, we can't trust anyone."  In this book, we realize that Dumbledore never left Harry with clear instructions about destroying the Horcruxes. Harry is flooded with anger and resentment towards someone he saw as a father-figure. Even Ron and Hermione stumble as they struggle to continue following Harry without a clear plan. I was astounded reading about their loyalty to Harry because they both have the choice to leave and go into hiding, but they stay with him out of love, compassion and friendship. But I think Dumbledore, being the clever man that he was, knew the the trio would be able to fit the missing pieces of the puzzle together. On Potterwatch, Kingsley Shacklebolt said,  "We're all human, aren't we? Every human life is worth the same, and worth saving."  Despite the dangers of supporting Harry, many others fight during the Second Wizarding War. The Weasleys, Neville Longbottom, Lee Jordan, Luna Lovegood and countless others could have backed out of this. However, they continue fighting Voldemort because it is the right thing to do. The part where the trio saw the bruises on Neville and Seamus really stood out to me. They were willing to go be tortured to stand up for what is right. The scary thing is this fictional resistance reflects the protests that happened in the past and present. It reminded me a bit of the African-American Civil Rights Movement, where thousands of brave protestors continued to fight for equal rights. However, JK Rowling also makes the story complex because nothing is black and white. We are revealed details about Dumbledore that make us believe he was not the saint we all thought he was. Some of his political views when he was younger are debatable. Harry believes goodness is a leaner road and refuses to acknowledge like Ron and Hermione do that Dumbledore was simply naive at the time. Snape is another character who was always portrayed as being malicious and evil, but he loved Lily. The love he had enabled his heart to change and protect the person Lily died trying to save. He understands Lily put herself in danger by fighting Lord Voldemort and honours her by doing the same. The part that made me cry the most in this book was Dobby's death... I was listening to the audiobook and just began balling my eyes out. It was hard for me to believe that Dobby was no longer here. Our innocent, brave and noble Dobby who was a guardian throughout the book to Harry. Dobby, the creature most people treated like scum, died protecting others and demonstrating more bravery than many humans out there. When Harry scribbled,  "Here lies Dobby, a Free Elf" , I seriously couldn't control my tears. I think his death touched me the most in the series. The way JK Rowling was able to discuss complex topics like death and afterlife in this book were breathtaking to me. This made the last few chapters some of the most beautiful I have ever read. Near the end of the book, Harry makes the choice to sacrifice himself for the greater good. The way JK Rowling describes this is amazing. Harry acknowledges he never appreciated the brilliance of his own body. When he conjures the dead using the Resurrection Stone, he is relieved to see the spirits of his loved ones looking happy and healthy. I think the possibility of being reunited with them provides reassurance to Harry. Time also takes a standstill as Harry walks into the forbidden forest because every single second seems precious. When Harry is attacked by the killing curse, he goes to Kings Cross station, a place that once divided the magical and muggle world and now divides life and death. I know a lot of fans were disappointed with the lack of information revealed in the epilogue, but I was reading an interview where JK Rowling commented on it. She said she wrote it over and over again, but she felt like everything revealed too much information. Although it was factual, she felt like it was not a good piece of writing. I might be in the minority, but I actually really liked the epilogue. I was glad Harry finally had a family, which was the one thing he desired the most. I was relieved to know that  "all was well"  when I ended the book series. Although I do agree it left me curious about lots of other characters, it was a nice way to end the series and keep some loop holes incase JK Rowling ever did decide to write an 8th book. This was my 3rd time re-reading this series and it was just as wonderful as I remember it. Although these books will always play a special role in my heart, I don't think I'll be re-reading them any time soon since I do want to continue forth on my reading journey and explore other books. But this is definitely a book series I'll go back to eventually and share with my future children. If you haven't experienced the wonders and magic of this captivating book, then I highly recommend you read it. :)

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: It took me over 3 months to complete this book. I was currently on a reading slump, but i am back at it. Anyways, I couldn't have asked for a better ending to the series. This book was the most eventful one in my opinion. It had its moments when it was slow paced, but other times it was all happening very fast (not in a bad way). This wasn't my favorite book of the whole series, but i still thought it was well written. My favorite scene was the battle at Hogwarts. It was as if i was physically there watching the events unfold until it reached the climax. I know i will have to revisit the series again someday due to all the minor details I could've missed. I will forever be thankful to J.K. Rowling for creating this iconic world and for entertaining millions of people. I find it fascinating how one person can come up with so much content and make an incredible story. If i had the chance to visit any fictional place, my answer would be Hogwarts.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: These books meant something to me in the past. A lot, actually.But that love has been tainted. I don't know that I can separate the art from the artist enough to even revisit - indeed the artist seems determined to not allow us to separate them from the art. My heart and conscience won't allow me to leave up my ratings and reviews for these books. No matter that my one small voice will hardly affect the massive industry that is Harry Potter. Maybe all our small voices together will.Trans lives matter. I will do all in my power to not allow them to be attached, hurt, or silenced. This is the very least of what I can, and do, do.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: Hey Book Peeps It’s 2:45 am right now and I need to go to work soon so I can’t write much but I will say that my first rating of a 3 stars was completely based on how fast I read this book the first time through. At the time this book came out, I was determined to re read Book 5 and Book 6 before starting this one so that I was completely refreshed before heading into this beast. I was also reading it during a Harry Potter con where I had to keep under raps that I was the only muggle alive who had not finished the book and who had not been spoiled yet LOL.I have to say because I was trying to superstar my reading life away, I wasn’t really absorbing the book and enjoying the way the plan all comes together. Now re reading it for the first time since 2007 ( OMG 11 years ago) I have to say that I think I love this book more then The Order of the Phoenix which was my ride or die book for this series. Believe me it hurt to say it but its true even though it is only by a hair. The fifth book will always have a place in my heart but I just loved this book. I loved the pacing and how the plot developed. I loved the character growth and the way the wizarding world was being changed by the events of an era and war. I think what really was the most captivating thing for me in this book was how much I learned about Albus Dumbledore.In my mind all these years he was the untouchable father figure who was pretty much a saint.He could do no wrong. I had him on such a high pedestal and he was the moral compass that always pointed North in my eyes. During this re read I realized that Albus is just a man and he is as flawed as any other muggle or wizard around . I think I appreciated it even more now as an adult because I understand that we can only wear so many hats in this life and we can not be everything to everyone at every point in time. Understanding of his flaws, letting us and Harry see him as only a man who has made mistakes, was so humbling. Learning about his life made me love him more than I ever had in any of the previous books. This was a fantastic culmination of many years of character development and world building and I am so happy that I was able to be part of it when it released. This series has changed my life in so many ways and there is not enough words to express the joy it has brought me.Okay immediate gush over. I am starting to cry. Happy reading you guys Jo

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: I have so many feelings inside of me !.It's always bittersweet to finish a series and, above all, to finish a series as incredibly famous as this one.It will be very difficult for me to review these wonderful books, which I'll probably do next year.I can anticipate that it has been a magical journey, full of teachings, growth, a fantastic story that will not be easy to forget, with some characters as original as few, and for which I have always had a special affection.As some know I'm a follower of the movies but for some reason I have always been intimidated to start with the books, but hey, that ends up happening. And I don't regret at all, always a book is richer in content than a movie, in this case I think the movies are wonderful but of course, a little more are the books .I want to summarize by saying that I don't consider myself as a big fan of HP, because that I feel that would be disrespecting those who really are, I know they are books that have a great fandom and I would never say that I'm part of it , if I don't really am, on the other hand I would say that I'm an admirer, because yes I have admired them, the writing style is beautiful , the plot as well, in short I have loved it, but I wouldn't call myself a fan.I hope to be able to write a properly review soon about these beautiful books, I'll be very sincere as I always try to be and I can't wait to do it :).

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: It's not a surprise that I give this book five stars. It's not a surprise that I cried while reading the last 100 pages. It's not a surprise that after rereading all seven books I am filled with so much love and joy but also sadness because I have to leave the Wizarding World and continue living the boring and plain muggle life. I will miss Harry, Ron, Hermione, the dream trio that allowed us to be a part of their adventures and journey. We grew up with them, we learned from their mistakes and we learned how to learn from these mistakes and be better. I will miss every other character as well, just to be clear!! My love for these books is absolutely endless. When you touch these books you feel accepted, a one of a kind warmth, you feel a special kind of magic, that you can't describe. There will be always a special place in my heart for the Harry Potter books. I will always find a way to return in the Wizarding world when I lack of magic in my life. "After all this time? Always." ❤

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: This book settles it: Dumbledore may be one of the greatest characters ever created in the world of fiction. As Rowling turns her universe upside-down and reveals the past of a man who is fully accepted as the greatest wizard of all time, she reveals a character depth beyond belief. Dumbledore is made out to be a sinner, a villain, a God-like figure who does not stand in the way for an innocent sacrifice. He is good, but he is focused on the greater good, sacrificing individuals in order to achieve his goal. He loves Harry, heart and soul, but he still needs him dead. And worst of all? He has coldblodily known it all the time. While people has celebrated Snape's surprising sacrifice, I will always celebrate Dumbledore's betrayal. Purity and peace doesn't come without a price, and Dumbledore is willing to pay. He is a brilliant exception in Rowling's black-and-white universe. (view spoiler)[Along with Harry Potter of course. The part of Voldemort that lives in him reminds us that no one is pure. That we all hold a bit of evil – even though it has been attached to us by accidental spells and curses. (hide spoiler)]One thing that has been clear to me on rereading these books, is how black-and-white Rowling usually operates. Like the sorting hat, she conveniently divides her characters into good and evil and very few outsteps this path. I have always found it cowardly, how this book dismisses Slytherin-pupils for instance. An entire house of people, thrown out of the defining battle because they happen to be wearing green and silver. Rowling spends the entire series preaching how Slytherin isn't necessarily defined by evil – and yet, she chooses to dismiss them, when the fight is about to come. I've always hated it. I have always hated how the Slytherins in the end only seem to be allowed a single character trait. This time around, I also had a bit of trouble grasping the scope of Voldemort's evil. Is he about to destroy the universe? Will his rise to power mean the end of muggle-life? And if so, will it mean the end of every muggle in the world, or is his power restricted to Britain only? Why does the world not send help to fight him – why does the Order not include African, American or even European wizards? Voldemort's power and evil seems unlimited, and yet he is fought by an underground army consisting of Britains only, fighting the ultimate battle at a schoolground. I am confused by the perspective; Voldemort could rule the world, crush every offender – and yet he is at Hogwarts, fighting children. The suspense is however undeniable. We don't have time for so many strategic questions while reading this book, because it is nerve-wracking to read. Rowling makes you forget time and space – and even plot holes – as she drags you along for break-in's, wandlore, secret missions and treasure hunts for pieces of an evil soul.I have always loved the horcruxes and the psychological insight they provide into both Harry and Voldemort's soul. Little by little, you become fascinated with Voldemort's anger and his desire to be accepted, and you even come to understand the darkest corners of Harry's soul. While the treasure hunt itself is a bit tedious at times, its ultimate goal is breathtaking. However, as much as I've always loved the horcruxes, I've always hated the Deathly Hallows. It's puzzling why no one has ever mention Beedle the Bard earlier, as his tales are supposed to be the mythic pillars of the wizarding world. Why has Hermione, who has read about every book of wizardry, never stumbled upon these ancient tales – and why has Ron, who has grown up with these stories and loved them forever, never mentioned them? Why isn't there a magic frog card with Beedle the Bard? Why has Rowling never let a bit of the enthralling tales slip earlier? It's all so sudden. And to me, it's a bit implausible. As is wandlore itself.Wandlore is mythical, wonderful to read about, and impossible to understand. I'm still not sure about the whole allegiance thing; how exactly a wand's power is transferred or why. It's messy and I'd have loved a bit more explanation.But of course, I'd loved a bit more of everything. I love this book – mostly because of Dumbledore's character development (even beyond his death), and because it is so actionpacked and gratifying. Seven books, read in the dark with a galloping heart, and then this wonderful ending, where only a few characters are spared, and all are forever marked. This book may be filled with errors, but I am willing to overlook them. It is hard not to as these wonderful characters has been part of my life for so long.The Harry Potter-books are magical. And magic is hard to define. (view spoiler)[ A final note: I hate the ending relationships. This is perhaps more related to book six than book seven, but I've never understood Ginny and Harry. We get no explanation, no gradual falling-in-love process; suddenly Harry is in love with Ginny, while one moment earlier he wasn't. There was so much potential; so many scenes at the Burrow, Rowling could have used in order to build these feelings. Instead Harry falls in love out of jealousy.And then there's Ron and Hermione – another relationship enabled by hurt and jealousy. I can understand why Ron loves Hermione, but I can't understand why she loves him. He has been mean to her, ridiculing her, never appreciated her and even hinted she was ugly on several occasions. Would you fall in love with someone, who asked you out as a last resort, and loudly exclaimed that no one else wanted to go out with you? Would you fall in love with someone who got angry on the same occasion, because you actually went with someone else? Someone who ignored you, because he didn't appreciate you enough to ask? Someone who created an entire relationship with another girl, because he was jealous of a relationship you had before he had even shown interest in you? I think not. Ron is a lovely person, but he never treated Hermione well. At least not in my opinion. (hide spoiler)]

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: [First read: 2007. 2 starsSecond read: 1st March, 2016. 3 stars.]Read as part of The Infinite Variety Reading Challenge, based on the BBC's Big Read Poll of 2003.Here's a big fat review (longer than I usually write, more rambling and less coherent) that will focus on the series as a whole, as well as just this book.The first time I read this book-all those years ago when it first came out-I was pretty much fed up with Harry Potter at that point. It was too big: nothing deserves to be that big, not even Jesus, and it was, quite frankly, boring. So I skipped through the book and didn't really pay much attention. I also didn't see the film until much, much later and as a whole, the big pile of fandom just passed me by in to the void of nothingness behind me.As the years passed by, I wanted to dip my toe back in. I was feeling a bit nostalgic, I admit, but I also wanted to see if the magic of Harry Potter that everyone was going on about was there for me, too. TLDR; it is not.This book, the final of the series, is definitely one of the best of the series but it has some serious faults. You can definitely see the pressure that J.K. was under from, oh look, you lot, to finish the book and get it out so they could make the next film. I don't think this was quite the ending she really wanted and that is quite a big disappointment, though we can't hold the author accountable. (It's all your fault, really.)We still have two protagonists who haven't changed much in seven years: Harry and Ron have been the same semi-intelligent, slightly amusing and stupidly brave boys that we met in the first book. Hermione, I am glad to say, has changed from book to book, though there were a few moments when she really went a bit dodgy. As far as the other characters, I have to say they were all pretty much background and dull. I still can't get over how Luna Lovegood just turns up and randomly becomes an important character without actually saying or doing much at all. I also think a lot more could have been done with Neville: I thought he was pretty great and the way he ended the series was wonderful. It's very difficult to enjoy a series of books when you don't like (not hate) the main character. Did anyone really care if Harry died at the end, as long as Voldemort did as well? I didn't.I was also not a fan of the way most of the unpleasant characters were either fat or ugly. Most of the weird characters were a bit odd-looking, as well, and it just felt like an easy get-out of having to think of interesting characters who didn't conform to type. The thing about fantasy is that it's usually mostly the locations and settings that really make it magical. Harry Potter is extremely limited in location and that really made it feel small and closed off. Yes, Hogwarts is a fun Scottish castle, but really how much do we know about Hogwarts; how much did we really see? We barely explore the place and the places around it. I understand that magical people are pretty much hidden away, but it always felt like such a lacking world. Hogwarts was no more magical than Harry's cupboard, really (enchanted ceiling notwithstanding).The Deathly Hallows never quite felt like the ending it should have been. It was definitely the best written of the set, which just shows how a writer learns from their previous mistakes (which, sadly, a lot of authors don't seem to do) and the flow from preceding book to the follow up was better than it had been earlier on.I can't really see myself ever reading these ever again, unless I really run out of things to read. I find that rather saddening, because I can remember a time in my childhood-during the first few years of the earlier books and films-when I really loved this series. I remember the two weeks I really wanted to be an actor so I could be in the film and elope with whoever it was that played Sirius (Gary Oldman, I know, but back then I didn't care). I strongly remember that I felt bad for being in love with Draco for about a year, too (I have a thing for blondes). I will look back fondly on my mis-remembered feelings on Luna and treasure my rekindled love for Hermione. I think I am incredibly lucky to be of an age where I grew up at the right time for this series, but I'm also not supremely disappointed that the magic is no longer there.Blog | Instagram | Twitter | Pinterest | Shop | Etsy

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: As a whole series, my average rating for the series ends up roughly around 4 stars. This is purely because once the series gets over its initial roughness, keeping the charm and developing the characters it becomes a very solid and imaginative series. It may not be the 'epic' that some people are looking for in their fantasy - but like The Chronicles of Narnia its a quirky and appealing little series. Let's be honest: nothing I say or do not say about this series will persuade or dissuade anyone from reading these books if they put their mind to either standpoint. All I can say is how I found the novels and with all honesty I found that they improved so much that I think I will actually miss not having another book in the series to move on and read. I'm a huge reader of fantasy and have been since my mother read The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe to me as a six year old child (I went on to read the novel for myself the following year). There's something about the way a truly great fantasy novel can take you to a whole other world (same with sci-fi) and yet remind you about real world concepts, themes, emotions and values that is appealing. So, I admit that when other children grew up on Harry Potter, I grew up on the novels which preceded Harry Potter. I grew up in Narnia, Middle Earth, Wonderland, Neverland and so on. So as I saw the hype for the Harry Potter series (coupled with the fact that my parents thought the books a touch too dark for my age) I may have decided to avoid reading them, thinking that they were copycats of other, better, books. How snobbish of me.I would easily add this series (for the improvement, character building, world etc.) to my list of unique fantasy series. Of course this would be a list featuring the before mentioned books and also anything by Brandon Sanderson (particularly his Mistborn books), The Wheel of Time (if you don't mind looooong drawn out epic fantasy tales) and The Name of the Wind (as far as it has gone till now). I definitely am willing to recommend any books that you might like if you grew up on Harry Potter or anything similar. Pardon my ramblings, all I wish to say is that I was very impressed with the series after being less than so with the first two and a half books. The other four fully make the most of the promise of the first few books however and therefore create works of fiction which perform all that I believe literature should do.In the novels there are subtle and nuanced reflections on education and the influence of governments and politics on daily life. Rowling seems to imply that while government is a great thing behind the scenes to keep the world running there are times when it meddles in the greater good. Leonard Nimoy (RIP) passed away earlier and he once said (in character) that 'the needs of the many outweigh the needs of the few'. I believe this is the concept that Rowling wished to convey about education and government. The few are in power and authority and it is their job to fulfill the needs of the many, not their own.I also love the final part of this novel with its very Christian message. In some ways Harry becomes a rough Christ figure in these novels (which has lead to the book's fair share of criticism such as how can you mix a message of faith with magic etc.) with how his love and sacrifice for his friends enables him to be able to defeat dark magic. It's a similar theme to that used in The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe but in a different way and I loved how it was used here. I was often told that the books were so non-Christian with the magic and everything but this conclusion is very Christian in how it conveys that evil is created through fear and a desire to become like God (all-powerful like Voldemort attempts to become) and that only sacrificial love can truly defeat the curse of evil. It's a great message and I would definitely not hide these books or ban them, I would encourage children to read them and then ask them questions about those themes!All in all, I definitely enjoyed the books and have also been enjoying the movies simultaneously. I wish in some senses that I had read them sooner and definitely recommend them for the story. Don't be sucked in by the hype, but do read them for their beautiful little story and thematic expression!

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: I finished late last night. I stayed awake to finish, because how could anyone stop reading during the epic epic epic end battle of this series!?Rereading Harry potter has been an amazing experience and I love how Rowie and I shared every step of the way. Rereading together also made sure I picked up the next book every month, otherwise my reread would have taken me 3 years or something, but I loved how we did this!This book is now my favorite of all. it gave me all the feels now I remember from all the other books the first time I've read them. in the other books, I had a lot of things that I did not really liked. Still all 5* of course, but I was not head over heels again with this series. This book gave me all those feelings, and made me fall head over heels completely in love with this world. I absolutely love how this book ends and concludes it all. I love the battle.I'm currently rewatching the movies, I've seen the first two, and I'm already excited to be watching the last two movies because I love this book so much now haha!What an amazing job Rowling has done to let the books grow with you. I will allow my children to read one every year from 11 y/o so that they also grow with them :)

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: "After all this time? Always."I've been staring at this blank box for over 10 minutes trying to think of a way to start reviewing the majesty of a book that was Deathly Hallows.There are truly too many emotions clouding my judgement at the moment, just give me a sec.First off I want to say that I'm utterly heartbroken, not only because this book was heartbreaking itself, but because I've just finished reading the Harry Potter series for the first time. I had seen the movies, many, many, MANY times, but I'd never picked up the books, don't ask me, I honestly don't know why. Now that it's over, I truly don't know what to do with myself, I'm so invested in this world, and in this story...to not have another book to look forward to is the most saddening thing. But, still, it was an indescribable experience, and I'm so glad I decided to start this journey back on September. I remember that I actually read Harry's first September 1st scene, on September 1st. I don't know why that brings me so much happiness. The coincidence made it feel like fate, and I DON'T CARE IF IT'S CHEESY, IT'S REAL.On to the good stuff: THIS BOOK WAS UNREAL. Everything, literally EVERYTHING was pure magic. Pun intended. This epic conclusion was, by far, the best series closer I've ever read in my life, nothing could beat this magnificent ending. Everything was so well explained, and thought-out, many loose-ends from other books were corrected in this conclusion, making every book essential, every pointless detail was taken into consideration, and made part of something bigger. That's where J. K. Rowling's true magic lies: being able to forge simple details and conversations into something so big, none of us could see it coming.Harry's, Ron's and Hermione's friendship was severely tested in this book, and their weaknesses were enhanced, so we got to witness the good, the bad, and the ugly that each character has, part because of the environment they endured for basically the whole book (being hunted 24/7, and having to live in the woods for a ridiculously long period of time) and because of the Horcruxes' effect. The whole deal with the Horcruxes was utterly fascinating, every aspect of it intrigued me, from Voldemort's fascination with conquering death, to how he came to know about the Horcruxes, to how he started making them, to the importance of his past, to the though-out locations where he hid them, to the effect they had on people, to how they had to be destroyed, and to the fact that he made a seventh unintended Horcrux that lived inside the boy he most desired to kill. The irony in all of it made me relish with amazement. Something I'd missed with the movies were the lengthy explanations that we get with the book, the explanations of why this Horcrux lived inside Harry, why he lived through two Killing Curses, and how Dumbledore wasn't truly the great man we thought he was.I'm not going to go into a lot of details about the book in case some of you haven't read it, or don't know what happens. Basically, I loved all of this:1. RON AND HERMIONE. -- this the book where Ron's actively trying to start things up with Hermione, with his love advice book at the beginning, and his distraught at Voldemort's Harry/Hermione ship (the scene when he destroys the Horcrux), and protecting her at EVERY moment. This book made Ron shine so much, through the ups and downs, we say an incredible, loyal man.2. HARRY AND GINNY. -- I mean. MUST I SAY MORE? I LOVE THEM.3. THAT EPILOGUE, MAN. -- Perfection. I do wish we'd gotten intel about what became of our three main characters: did Harry become an Auror? What did Hermione & Ron end up doing?4. The EPIC HOGWARTS BATTLE -- Neville. UGH what a SWEETHEART.5. EVERYTHING THAT HAD TO DO WITH HORCRUXES -- finding them, their locations, what they were, how to destroy them, their meaning, EVERYTHING.6. DEATHLY HALLOWS -- I ESPECIALLY loved the scene where they share the myth revolving the three objects.7. HAGRID -- THAT MAN KILLS ME. He's a sweetheart, and everything he does and says will always be beautiful to me. The scene where he has to carry Harry's body. Jesus. That scene is powerful. It brings everything full circle. 8. Kreacher's redemption: DEAR LORD, this elf was the death of me. I used to hate his GUTS, and in the movie, his redemption didn't happen, but in the book it did, and it was beautiful. He helped Harry, Ron & Hermione get one of the Horcruxes, and he had a hand in the final epic battle, where he led the elves against Voldemort's army.9. Dobby: Dobby was very painful. I can't quite put into words how much I loved this character and the sadness his ending caused me. 10. I LOVED the breaking into the Ministry's scene. EPIC. And breaking into Gringotts was SO MUCH FUN, Hermione's impression of Bellatrix was everything.11. SNAPE'S TRUTH: This was my absolute favorite part of the book. When we (FINALLY!) get to see his memories, and see how he's been protecting Harry all this time, was truly on our side, and beautiful his character actually was... He wasn't perfect. He wasn't a great guy. He had his flaws. But he was real. He was loyal, to a fault. He protected, even when sometimes he shouldn't. He was a magnificent character with an incredible arc, without a doubt my favorite character of all-time. Watching him during this book was heartbreaking, but the end was worth it. When Harry finally found out the truth...it was worth it. Silver doe. SILVER DOE. Enough said. I'm done. No more.12. "Not my daughter, YOU BITCH" -- epic.When Percy came back, to help in the Hogwarts battle... I broke down. I broke down BAD. And his stunning scene with Fred... where Perce made that joke. I still can't quite put into words how much it affected me. My heart breaks. Every time.As I said, this was an amazing experience, I can't wait to reread them, and then re-read all my reviews. It's been amazing.I really can't say more, I keep crying every time I write a new bullet, so I'm gonna go, watch the final two movies, and cry some more. If you're still here, thank you for reading. You're the best. <3

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: Ratings:Stars: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ (5/5)Plot: 👑👑👑👑👑👑 (5/5)How Much I enjoyed it: 💙💙💙💙💙 (5/5)A good morning/afternoon/evening to you muggle/witch/wizard! Here is my review on The Deathly Hallows book! I put on my Ravenclaw Diadem on for it😜😜😜It would be an insult to the book if I simply stated ‘I love this book’. I mean, look at that opening sentence. The two men appeared out of nowhere, a few yards apart in the narrow, moonlit laneI mean like.. who could resist that sentence?!?!I have a deep opinion about the Deathly Hallows:The Invisibility Cloak:*I could eat unlimited chocolate from the fridge at midnight without creeping any of my family members*I could get out of the house without getting in trouble*I could ride a motorcycle and freak people out to make them think it was self driving*I could surprise my cousins at their doorstep at the other side of the world*I could go places like movie theaters and concerts would be accessible without fee.*I could be a fantastic hide-n-seek player.(which I'm usually terrible at)* And my personal favorite, you could pull some pretty scary pranks on Halloween.But with the Resurrection Stone:*I could bring my favorite people back to life*I could make other people happy with the power of it *I could make 'grumpy' people 'ungrumpy' (I don't know if that's a word)With the Elder Wand though:*I COULD BECOME INVISIBLE WITHOUT the Invisibility Cloak!!!*I could beat up alot of bullies and people I don't like (like... OK, some people aren't gonna like this but.... okay... I'm not gonna say.. if you really) wanna know just tell me*It's a combination of a cloak and a wand ultimately powerful undefeatable wand and a cloak that can make your greatest dreams of a midnight chocolate frog fiesta true!!!!! ____________________________________All you need to know about Horcruxes:A Horcrux was an object in which a Dark wizard or witch had hidden a fragment of his or her soul in order to become immortal. Horcruxes could only be created after committing murder, the supreme act of evil. The Horcrux was considered to be the darkest art and the most terrible of all dark magic.Voldermort's horcruxes were:⦿Tom Riddle's diary. ⦿Marvolo Gaunt's Ring. ⦿Salazar Slytherin's Locket. ⦿Helga Hufflepuff's Cup. ⦿Rowena Ravenclaw's Diadem. ⦿Harry Potter (unknown to Voldemort until after he had "destroyed" him) -> Destroyed in Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows⦿Nagini the Snake (Was previously a woman)It is perhaps interesting that no person destroyed more than one Horcrux. Harry, Ron, Hermione, Neville, Dumbledore, Crabbe (indirectly: the diadem fell apart in Harry's hands after being damaged by Crabbe's fiendfyre), and Voldemort each destroyed one of the seven.So the destroyers and which horcrux they destroyed are:Tom Riddle’s Diary- Before his demise, Voldemort gave his Diary to Lucius Malfoy. Malfoy gave it to Ginny Weasley both to get rid of it and discredit Arthur. It caused a lot of trouble and possessed Ginny, though it was destroyed by Harry Potter in the Chamber of Secrets by a Basilisk fang. This one was arguably 100% luck.Marvolo Gaunt’s ring-destroyed by Albus Dumbledore behind the scenes by Gryffindor’s sword, though it pretty much cost him his lifeSlytherin’s Locket- after being carried around by the trio for months and causing a lot of trouble, it was destroyed by Ron Weasley in an unknown forest using Gryffindor’s sword. It didn’t go without a fight, however, and made Ron see his worst fear, such as the fact that Harry and Hermione both like each other more than him.Hufflepuff’s cup- retrieved from the Lestrange vault in Gringotts Bank by the trio, it was destroyed by a Basilisk fang in the Chamber of Secrets during the Battle of Hogwarts.Ravenclaw’s diadem- found and destroyed in the Room of Requirement by Fiendfyre cast by Vincent Crabbe. Crabbe was killed by his own curse.Nagini- killed by Neville Longbottom using Gryffindor’s sword during the Battle of Hogwarts. Neville has just bravely stood up to Voldemort and had the Sorting Hat placed on his head and lit aflame. Neville pulled the sword out and cut Nagini in half.Harry Potter- killed by Voldemort’s Avada Kedavra in the Forbidden Forest on the second day of the Battle of Hogwarts. Harry survived due to his true ownership of the Elder Wand, which would not kill its own master.Voldemort- killed due to his own rebounding curse. Harry cast expelliarmus and Voldemort cast Avada Kedavra, and once again the Elder Wand would not kill Harry. The both curses hit Voldemort, and Harry caught the Elder Wand while Voldemort died.And how could I end without any quotes?Albus Dumbledore:Of course it is happening inside your head, Harry, but why on earth should that mean that it is not real?Do not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all those who live without loveDumbledore watched her fly away, and as her silvery glow faded he turned back to Snape, and his eyes were full of tears.After all this time?Always," said Snape. (Potterheads like me start to cry over Lily's death)Harry Potter & Ron Weasley:Death's got an Invisibility Cloak?" Harry interrupted again.So he can sneak up on people," said Ron. "Sometimes he gets bored of running at them, flapping his arms and shrieking... (Potterheads exploding with laughter)And what in the name of Merlin's most baggy Y-fronts was that about? (Every Potterhead in the universe still shocked that of all people Hermione said 'Merlin's pants!')If we die for them I'll kill you, Harry! (Everyone sharpening their swords to kill Harry for saving Draco)That is all, muggles, witches and wizards!(What's your house? I'm Ravenclaw! 😉😉)View this review on my blog orView all my reviews here

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: "It is a curious thing, Harry, but perhaps those who are best suited to power are those who have never sought it. Those who, like you, have leadership thrust upon them, and take up the mantle because they must, and find to their own surprise that they wear it well." (718) -Albus Dumbledore Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows ends the series on a particularly sweet note for fans who have grown up reading about Harry, Ron, Hermoine, and the entire wonderful cast of characters and creatures who inhabit it's lore. The book begins in a rather depressing way. Dumbledore has passed on and Harry is left to finish his fight against Voldemort who has slowly gained power over the past six novels; enough to control the ministry of magic and leave Potter and any witches/wizards who rise against him to flee into hiding. A good portion of the book has Harry on the run, and while meant to be despairing, this is where the book tends to drag a little. However, the build-up to the epic conclusion is something that brings up very fond memories of growing up reading this series over 10 years or so and grinning foolishly like a total fanboy at how J.K. Rowling managed to tie the series all together. Two chapters in particular, "The Princes Tale" and "King's Cross" are so exceptional in giving backstory to Severus Snape and Albus Dumbledore that they are so thrilling to read and uncover. What a grand journey this has been for readers.Rating 4.5/5

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: This review can also be found on my blog here.I can’t believe it’s over, these past two months i have been completely consumed in the wizarding world and now, its over and it feels so finalised! Throughout reading these books i continued to ask myself “why did you not read these books earlier?” but now i am actually happy i waited till now at a time in my life when i can truly understand everything that Harry goes through and pick up on the lessons that you learn throughout. Such a gripping and empowering book that i will probably cherish forever.I think with being her last book, J.K Rowlings writing flourishes here. It still has everything we expect from her, the comradery, love, adventure and humour, but with so much more feeling to it, that in just the way she wrote out certain moments could change my mood. It was incredible. I also found her writing expanding to areas she had only touched on before. Things concerning grief, power struggles and the strains of friendship that i think she worked through really well. Super impressed with the writing in this one.I can’t get over how much I loved this story. the last book ends with them planning a quest to find the Horcruxes and this is exactly what the majority of the story focuses on. It really is the be all end all kind of thing, because if they don’t find them, then all is lost, and you definitely feel that pressure on the trio throughout the book.Many parts were a bit slow and depressing when they felt they had nowhere to turn and didn’t know what to do next, but again, that despair makes it more real for the reader in understanding what they’re going through. So that didn’t bother me too much. However, there were some lovely moments that we get to see of everyone in the order together again, the Weasley family, Harry’s trip down memory lane and of course the DA members coming back a little. J.K Rowling really knows how to tug at your heartstrings and it is no different in this book!The plot is actually so encapsulating, due to it really being the end of Harry’s story and as it progresses you feel it building up and you know the defining moment is coming but you still don’t know what that will be. It’s all just so much to deal with at once and it felt overpowering towards the end of the book. It was perfect though, because i know that is exactly the way Harry feels at the time, and J.K Rowling did that on purpose so we would understand how much of a toll everything is taking on him. SOOOO many emotions guys, i can’t even begin to explain how this book made me feel.As far as “character developments” go i thought there wouldn’t really be more considering this is the seventh and final book, but this is the point in which Harry truly becomes a man and we see how different he really is from not only Voldemort but Dumbledore also. Harry really is a unique and realistic character who i have come to adore. He makes mistakes, he gets confused, he is brave but still terrified of things he has to do and i have come to appreciate it all.We get a lot of Hermione and Ron in this book, being that they are with Harry for the majority of the story on his travels and for the first time we really see a crack in their relationship, but what i love is how J.K Rowling works with this to make them all the better friends. So much love and determination from these two and they really are what makes the book all that more special.One thing i definitely wanted to talk about are the deaths. There is a lot of death in this book. Some big blows and some small but all are very significant to Harry in this battle he is fighting. I think because there is seven books and we get that time to really bond with the secondary characters that when one of them dies, it feels like someone you actually know. This book had me bawling for the last 100 pages and i just couldn’t believe what i was reading. You know someone is a great author when they can do that to you!Lastly, i just want to say how impressed i am that J.K Rowling made it possible to do her traditional end of the book info dump on us in such an extraordinary way in the “Kings Cross” place. What a cheeky author making that possible but I love her all the more for it. Love those conversations, we learn so much!Honestly, such a freaking fantastic series and it all came to a very poetic end, that personally suited me just fine. I adored the story of Harry’s crazy, daring and loving life and i feel like i am apart of it in some way, as is everyone who reads these books and goes on the adventures with Harry. Loved it.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: The bar of expectation has been set phenomenally high for Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows. And the book not only meets the expectations, but exceeds them.The themes examined in this book are quite mature: how governments twist the truth, how newspapers and media, as the voice of the government, feed misinformation for all sorts of reasons, how trusted adults may have dark pasts and not-so-pure motives. We're past the "simple" issues of revenge and love and well into far more complex agendas.Many children's books (fairy tales) have clear sets of morals and well-defined heroes and enemies: the wicked stepmother, the beautiful princess, the knight in shining armor. This final volume is much more grey; the lines of black and white, good and evil, are not so clear-cut in this book. This is probably very unsettling for younger readers who need to feel secure in a world where grown-ups can be trusted. For more mature readers, this is a beautiful example of peeling back the layers of the onion of life. The series began with a very innocent view of the world, from the viewpoint of a young Harry Potter. As he aged and matured, so did our ability to see what was happening, and we saw his attempts to understand the reason for the actions of his teachers, his friends' parents, and other characters in his ever-expanding world.In Deathly Hallows, Harry is now an adult. He has turned 17, age of adulthood for wizards. He is no longer safe with his aunt and uncle, the protective spell now removed. He can take control of his own actions and path in life. As we all know (and maybe even learned the hard way), this is hardly the freedom that teenagers think it will be. That freedom to rule your own life brings the responsibility for how your actions will affect those around you, the ones that you care for. Harry's choices have a huge impact on Hermoine and Ron, and many, many others who valiantly stand by their friend.In one sense, Harry has been set on a path by Dumbledore, and perhaps all that happens is Dumbledore's fault. On the other hand, Harry has free will, and Dumbledore's instructions have always been vague at best. Harry has quite a range of choice in what he does and does not do. Almost every one of those choices are difficult at best.There are meditations here on the meaning of death and life, on the value of sacrifice. Every character has known pain and has made decisions for selfish reasons. There are celebrations of new beginnings, and there are some endings as well. These mediations shows up often in fine literature; this imagery has been around since mankind began civilization and it is an integral part of how our society works. It is central to this Deathly Hollows, and the book wouldn't be nearly as successful if Ms. Rowling didn't address these thoughts.People looking for non-stop high school hijinks and game competitions will be disappointed. This final novel has none of that. In fact, there are long stretches where the characters feel stymied, and it feels like no progress is being made. The book forces the reader to slow down, to think deeply about what is going on, to feel the strain and pressure of achieving extremely difficult goals. There are action sequences and well-described battles, but these are the exception, not the rule. Deathly Hallows is about intense internal struggles and deeply emotional challenges.The vocabulary reflects this as well. This book is not meant to be skimmed or jumped through. The wording and the sentence structure encourage the reader to go slowly, to contemplate, to think about what is being said. While Harry spends weeks contemplating issues and trying to figure out how he feels about an issue, the reader is encouraged to do the same. It's an adventure of self-exploration.As I already mentioned, the bar was set exceedingly high for this book. It was expected to be exactly perfect, a stunning work of literature appropriate for every age group. It was expected to satisfy both those who wanted a blockbuster "Hollywood Ending" as well as those who feel realism requires death, destruction, and bleak despair. While it did not quite achieve all of those goals (it came REALLY close), it is an outstanding book which has exposed millions of people to questions and issues they might not have otherwise encountered. It encourages people to think about the world they live in. You cannot ask any book to do much more than that.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: *spoilers*This is officially my very first time I’ve completely re-read this series and it’s quite possible that I love it even more than I did before. Reading all books back to back (I started the first one in October and finished the last one in January) only made it even more apparent what an incredible saga that Rowling gifted us. All the linked parts, the character development, and just how astonishing it was to see it all unfold. Somehow it still managed to leave me awed even knowing how it all ends. While my opinions of the series as a whole didn’t change (other than the fact that my favorite book is now officially Half-Blood Prince and I’ve gotten over my irritation with Dobby) there is one aspect in these stories that I paid a lot more attention to this go around: Dumbledore and Snape.First and foremost, I’m team Snape (and a Slytherin if you were curious). Yes, I am fully aware that he was a horrible shithead to a bunch of children, primarily Harry, and the only reason was because he loved Harry’s mother and she didn’t love him. Boo-hoo. I’m also aware that he was a Death Eater doing terrible things on behalf of Voldemort before he joined up with Dumbeldore. I’m aware of all these things but I can still appreciate the bravery and risks he took in the name of love, even it was misguided. It doesn’t necessarily make him a hero in my eyes and his actions don’t make up for the wrong he did, but it is still worthy of mention. Don’t agree?hahaha Kidding. But on to an even more controversial topic: Dumbledore was kind of a dick. Sure, at first he’s that kind, fatherly figure that Harry can’t help but look up to. But when year after year at Hogwarts passes and poor young Harry is dealing with shit that he can barely comprehend, does Dumbledore make it a point to educate him on the ways of the wizarding world? Nope. And when we finally realize what’s been going on this entire time? That he’s known from the very beginning that Harry was going to have to die for the “greater good”?!Sure, if he had told Harry at an early age he could have lost his marbles at the prospect of an early death so I understand why he didn’t tell him but I definitely don’t agree with it because he didn’t treat Harry like a pawn; he treated him like he was someone special to him. Think of all the times that Harry was touting Dumbledore’s greatness while from the very beginning he’s known the endgame all along.Leave an infant on a doorstep, don’t even ring the doorbell. They’ll find him in the morning. Know Harry’s living in a goddamn cupboard under the stairs, constantly abused by the Dursley’s–does nothing. Let Snape continue to mistreat him unnecessarily. Blames it on the fact he developed feelings for the reason why he’s lied to Harry his entire life… talk about emotional manipulation. Not letting Harry in on the secret of the horcruxes until after he was doomed to die because his dumbass, for personal advancement reasons, put it on because it was also a Hallow. Dick move, Dumbledore. /rantRowling really achieved greatness with this final installment. Each installment has progressively gotten darker as Harry and all other characters take step after step into adulthood. This world that Rowling has created is both horrible and mesmerizing in equal measure. A world where there are creatures that can suck out your very soul, but also wondrous creatures like unicorns and Hippogriffs. A world where you can be struck down with two simple words, but also where owls deliver your mail and paintings talk. But the most wondrous thing that Rowling accomplished with these stories is just how many lives she transformed, mine included. It’s enough to make anyone believe in magic.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: IT IS NOT FOR ALL CHILDREN some SHELTERED CHILDREN might not be permitted by parents to read such harsh language and killing scenes.Some CHILDREN might not be educated enough to understand the plot and deep messages this book does have, which are intended for adult readers.Yes, some CHILDREN may be ready for this type of story, but many are not, due to parental restrictions in their lives.I firmly believe if a child has lived through horrid events then they will be able to read this. I guess sometimes it was hard for me to imagine that there was someone writing these remarkable stories. I really started to feel the characters after seeing the movies. I could hear them in my head their accents and everything!I forgot that there was a WOMAN behind the scenes. Someone a lot like me.J.K. Rowling was a single mother of two kids and on welfare! She started the books not really understanding what an impact they would make in people's lives!She never thought her books would be banned and hated my many people.Or that many billions more would LOVE her and her brilliant writing skills.I have learned that we all are magical beings. No matter what religion we are, we have love, bravery and imaginations...we are creative and romantic...There is a story in all of our hearts. I found that I have been fighting DEMENTORS and Voldemort's for a long time. I found that my own life struggles are a lesson for me. A journey I must take sometimes alone and sometimes with friends or family.Before I read Deathly Hallows I understood something, Death is a part of our Lives. We cannot survive one without the other. If we are not born we would not die.We must do both.I knew this before reading the last book.I have the Magic in me to survive death, by walking right into it when the time comes.It will not be a terrible thing, only leaving behind the ones we love and knowing that they will miss us sorely. Knowing that and end of our journey here the end of our story...the book will be replaced on the shelve and maybe not read again for a long time...When someone we love takes a photo of us or a letter we wrote long ago while we lived, and read it and for a moment remember us and we will be alive again in a memory in a heart beat in the tears...We will be once more remembered and for a few moments alive...and then we will rest again...a memory for another day. Inside the hearts of those who love us we will remain alive and warm and LOVED...Our spirit will have long journeyed on to a new place a new time making more friends and families and stories...I love my mind how it is.I might not be societies perfect person but who is?I have flaws.I am moody and emotional. I love too much and give of myself. I am a great friend and mother. A healer and artist and creator of stories and I grow plants and care for animals...I am human.I am me.And J.K. Rowling where ever you may be, THANKS I did enjoy my travels with you and Harry and ALL those wonderful people you created to become a part of my life and memories. Because it will add some excitement to the pages of my life-book! I am sure my girls will always remember my nerdish obsession with HARRY POTTER.THIS BOOK: HARRY POTTER AND THE DEATHLY HALLOWS Is not for ALL children under the age of oh let's say 10.It is full of death and killing. Of course it was coming, all this drastic drama, but I really do not see a reason for J.K. Rowling to feel she needed to kill certain people.I will not spoil WHO gets the axe, but I have never cried so much in any of these books!However in LIFE there comes DEATH, and some people must stand up and choose between what is RIGHT and what is EASY!And I will always remember the ones who gave their lives in this book to make the Witch & Wizarding world safe once more!A great read, I am planning to keep this as all the books in my collection for as long as I live. I will re read them all again and again.I wait for the MOVIES 6 and 7!THANKS! Nikki Jo

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: WELL I FINISHED THE HARRY POTTER SERIES!!!Three years ago I decided to finally pick up a little book called, "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone." Granted I wasn't in middle school or being read to before bed: nope I was 21 years old and enjoyed them just as much if maybe not more for waiting. I know this has been said plenty of times before me, but JK Rowling created a legacy for herself with writing these books. The first four were so wonderful and even though the next 3 books (plot-wise) went downhill for me, this ending had me smiling and reminded me why these books are so much more than children's tales. There are so many great moments throughout this series and these characters are some I am never going to find and love in other books as much as I do in these books. Hagrid always remained a favorite, along with Ron Weasley and of course Dumbledore!! The boarding of the scarlet train to Hogwarts scenes were another magical yet simply beautiful piece to the story. HEDWIG!! Hermonine and the house elves, Christmas at Hogwarts, Hagrid's dragon Norbert, and the wise and wonderful words of Dumbledore about love for each other. It's a bittersweet feeling completing this series. ALL WAS WELL.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: i’m not sure if i will be able to articulate any of this in a way that makes sense and truly expresses how i feel. i was terrified to read this. mainly because i knew it was the end of something that was so quick to become a favorite (and a personality trait). i have never said “i love this so much” during a book—especially the things reached a deadlock. i’ve also never cried so hard—especially for someone who realized he was alive. one thing i’ve always appreciate is the twists jkr implements, especially when they take a book or two to surface. i thought i despises certain characters, but now i’m rethinking. i will never be able to express how much this series means to me. there is no doubt in my mind that this series will stay with me. this book alone is probably my all time favorite. i’ll never forget those who died fighting for what was right, either. with that said, i will never forgive jkr for not giving draco the redemption arc he deserved or how she treated slytherins (don’t get me started on how she is in real life).at the end of the day... i loved every minute of this. i love these characters and i always will.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: At this point, I am so biased, J.K Rowling could have made Voldemort and Dumbledore become friends, start a business together, fall in love, get married, and adopt Harry, and I think I would have loved it. That said, this is the first time I felt strange after finishing a Harry Potter book. Once I had finished crying, it dawned on me how very unlike the other books it was. Maybe it's because it's the only one I haven't read 2-10 times, but it felt unfamiliar. I think it was probably the lack of Hogwarts. The school was such a big part of the books, it was weird for this book to take place elsewhere. In the end, I was happy with how everything went. I don't think it would be possible to please everybody, but after a decade of writing, J.K. wrote a marvellous ending to the series, despite the fact Harry named one of his children (view spoiler)[Albus Severus. (hide spoiler)] Whenever I think back to my childhood/adolescence, I will think of Harry Potter, and the wonderfully fond memories I have of him. Thanks, J.K.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: I just can't believe it's over.This fantastic series has given me so incredibly much - I don't even know how to describe it. It has helped me through some really bad days, and it has made me feel a lot better on so many occasions. I just love the world, its characters, the friendships, the plot, the humor - everything! Absolutely everything. And I actually think that Harry Potter is my number one favorite series of all time, and that it somehow always will be. Just the fact that this series exists in the world makes me so extremely happy to think about - that a lot of children, teenagers and adults can enjoy them over and over again, laugh and cry at the same parts, fall in love with the same characters, be highly engaged in the same world and all its happenings, and just take part in an amazing journey and feel all the magic for themselves. As said, these books existence simply makes me so very happy just to think about, and that says quite a lot about my love for them.I can't wait to reread this series again - and again and again and again.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: I'm lacking of words right now, but I'll try and form a decent review for such a decent, marvellous, outstanding book.As a series, it is completely obvious that J.K. Rowling beat herself writing this beauty, creating a whole new world out of scratch, with all its details and personalities is just awe inspiring. Coming to speak of this particular tome, it was beautiful and enormously tear shedding. I cannot add more words to express how much I loved the series and how I admire all of the characters, every single event and the intelligence of the writer.Huge thanks to everyone who has advised me to read the series, I owe you big time! text: 3.5 stars!  This one I actually enjoyed, after having the hardest time with books 5 and 6. The Deathly Hallows is the last book in the Harry Potter series and I feel like it was a long time coming: the last two books were pretty slow and unnecessarily long. However, this had more action and I had a nice time reading it (actually, listening to the audiobook, which has great narration). I appreciated the journey to find the horcruxes and deathly hallows, and the conclusion was satisfying.It was a goal to finish the series before the end of the year, and I’m glad I did.
