book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: third time’s the charm? the first time i read the book, i was happy that it was terrible. the second time, disappointed. this time, the book doesn’t do what i wanted it to do and what should happen, but it’s not entirely terrible.1. in half blood prince, dumbledore speaks at length about how evil is self-defeating. i think jkr must have felt a kind of responsibility to make evil seem unattractive (maybe because of how troubled she was that draco was a fan favourite) ergo pureblood obsession leads to becoming insane, poor, ugly, bestial. voldemort is powerful technically but also weak, blind, cowardly, and mad. his defeat is not because harry is particularly able but because of his own failings. one of the most skilled legillimens in the world (he’s been doing this since early childhood, before he knew he was a wizard) has somehow has forgotten what occulmency is and allows harry to see his mind and even his thoughts without realizing this is happening because he’s so out of control. i feel harry being able to read voldemort’s actual thoughts is jkr’s way of showing us that dumbledore’s fanfic of riddle was correct; he’s a 101 study in abnormal psychology whose every move can be predicted because he is such a limited person with such a limited understanding of others. this is just not very satisfying. evil being self-defeating isn’t really a thing, and making the villain of the story pathetic isn’t interesting to read. in the previous book, it was also revealed that voldemort's whole understanding of his mother as the victim of a muggle was incorrect - she was the victim of her pureblood family, and in turn, victimized voldemort's muggle father. jkr gives voldemort no legitimate basis for his prejudice towards muggles whatsoever... which is a choice. i wonder if jkr did this so she could give this plotline to dumbledore's family instead.2. i think jkr's problems with writing voldemort is part of a larger issue she has with depicting slytherin characters with complexity, which is why the inter-house unity plotline was abandoned. it feels a little like jkr exhausted herself by coming up with two slytherins that weren't completely evil - draco, who found the actual business of being in a terrorist group too gory (though i approve of everything she’s done with draco), and snape, who decided terrorism was bad because it threatened the woman he was freakishly obsessed with. i think the closest jkr really gets is with regulus but his narrative is very contained. it's a little annoying to me that voldemort, sirius and phineas nigellus never find out that regulus stole that horcrux. snape being remembered while regulus seems forgotten feels wrong.3. i don’t actually mind the hallows plot in itself. what does bother me is that there hasn’t been really a trace of this before, and that the traces we do have don’t fit (why can a magical eye see through the invisibility cloak it if it’s so unique? how does this concept of mastering wands work - does it apply to when kids disarm each other in classes?) also that this is lore only known to those with wizarding families. voldemort’s failure is precisely because of his muggle background. dumbledore tries to say it's because voldemort sees fairy tales as beneath him, but this doesn’t really fit; hermione didn’t believe it either, and that lack of faith in fairy tales isn’t a moral failing, nor is ignorance of the stories themselves. the idea that riddle wouldn’t care about wizarding lore because he sees it as beneath him also doesn’t seem to fit with him spending five years tracking down the mythical chamber of secrets. really, given that harry has the cloak because of his ancestor, the whole hallows plot is a weirdly elitist kind of argument being made about people who understand wizarding culture because they are embedded in it vs those who don’t. also we don’t need voldemort and harry to be related. it’s odd that jkr kills the voldemort/harry parallels entirely but makes them actually related. 4. the wizards vs other magical beings plot should have started much earlier on in the series. the issues with the goblins in particular could have been brought up in the very first book; jkr gives us a few random facts about goblin rebellions in pretty much every book but nothing that leads to what she’s attempting here. (i also feel that the goblin concept of ownership may be based on something jkr read about indigenous understandings of property rights, and if so, there are some nasty implications there, just as there were when she drew a comparison between werewolves and being hiv positive.) there was a real attempt to build the house elf plotline, but unfortunately, jkr didn’t know how to resolve it.5. in terms of specific character issues, i'm still not okay with harry casually using unforgivable curses. harry not being able to use unforgivable curses is a major plot point in the last two books.... his horror at sectumsempra was true to his character; crucio'ing a death eater for spitting at mcgonagall is not. ron is written in an extremely irritating way; yes, people struggle with being insecure all their lives but no one wants to read about a character's cruel, jealous and petty shit for seven books. ron could have grown out of his insecurities by becoming actually good at something instead of implausibly opening the chamber of secrets, and inexplicably 'winning' hermione. ginny is written very oddly; her obedience to harry is really disturbing given that they'd only been dating for one month when they broke up, and that she doesn't have a significant role against voldemort is poor writing. molly vs bellatrix is also poor writing; once again we have jkr's good woman vs bad woman theme, and it's ugly that sirius' killer (and the longbottoms' torturer) is killed by someone who had no personal grievance with her and also actively disliked sirius. lupin (and tonks! because in the last two books, tonks has just turned into lupin's appendage) dying offpage so that the marauders are all neatly dead and the weasley family can be preserved is also very ugly. re: snape, going with the incel angle was a decidedly weird choice but what makes it really unforgivable is jkr pressing the idea that dumbledore (and harry) believe that snape genuinely loved lily when what she wrote clearly says he didn't. i also don’t see the point in introducing dean or ted tonks at all. dean here is so disconnected from the trio even though he was on the quidditch team, dated ron’s sister, and lived with them for six years. ted tonks should have been cut because how are we to care about tonks' family when jkr hasn't even bothered writing anything re: tonks other than she's obsessed with lupin?6. i’m not really sure what i loved about harry potter when i was in fandom. i know i was incredibly disappointed in what she did in half blood prince, and i had pretty much the same criticisms as i do now, but what was the specific draw for me then? now, what i appreciate about the series is how harry’s grief is so close to the surface.“But it seemed that to Dumbledore, the fact that their families lay side by side in the same graveyard had been an unimportant coincidence, irrelevant, perhaps, to the job he wanted Harry to do.”no one quite gets it. hermione pathologizes and ron ranges from careless to callous. harry is just very alone with the weight of all of it and maybe that’s why he’s remains a compelling character in spite of all the poor choices jkr made.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: “Do not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living and, above all, pity those who live without love.”Ah, the final book. It’s still always so sad when the Harry Potter binge comes to an end. I’m going to try and keep this review brief, to avoid recycling the same fan girl ramblings from my previous reviews.While this is a five star read I do feel like everyone is a little bit lost without Hogwarts, at least at the beginning. It doesn’t take long for the momentum to pick up but it definitely feels different to the rest.Highlights: Neville. How’s that character development?! What. A. Guy.McGonagall. She’s just a total badass, always has been, and Hogwarts is so lucky to have her. That moment between her, Harry and the Carrows perfectly depicts how much respect we should all show for this woman and I’m so glad it happened.Kreacher! I’d have to put his character development pretty close with Neville’s. He comes so far and his actions in this book just made my heart happy.Snape. Yes, he unnecessarily bullies the kids and that’s not okay but his story, his bravery and sacrifices just break my heart. Snape gets all my love.The major highlight though, is the execution of this as the final book. Everything that was hinted at, all of the questions that had remained unanswered, it all ties in beautifully and leaves me with so much respect for the level of detail and forethought put into this series.My one big gripe - that off the page death! I get it, there’s a lot going on at that point, but you cannot kill off one of the sweetest people to have ever existed, and someone I deem to be a pretty important character, and not take the time to explain that and let us process what this means. This character deserved so much better.And that, my friends, is my ‘brief’ review 🙄Every time I revisit these books I find myself appreciating characters that maybe I’d overlooked previously. Outside of my usual favs (McGonagall, Dumbledore, Sirius, Hagrid and Snape) props this time around go to Mr Weasley, Dobby, Kreacher, Neville, and above all, Lupin.“Until the very end.”

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: Well ahh, I'm the 26,372nd person to review this, so I guess there's not much I can say that hasn't already been said. So, Harry Potter. I finally finished reading all of them. It took me forever and a day, but I did it! For some reason this one took me a particularly long time. Don't know why. I kept being like, "*Reads five pages* .... OKAY! Off to do something else." I guess because it was a little slow starting out. The first half of it was a lot of sitting around in the woods and being like *ARGUE ARGUE ARGUE* But, it got a lot better as it went along. I know J.K. Rowling did have to tie up a lot of things, so that's probably why it was so long and had so much information, etc.Anyway. So I read the second half of it in the car on a 2-hour ride home from Connecticut about a week ago. And toward the end it was getting dark outside, so I had to use my iPod as a flashlight and it was rather difficult and I was getting a headache. But I was like, "MUST. FINISH." It was a good ending. Very satisfying. I've heard people complain about the ending being too happy and whatnot, but it wasn't really ... I mean, half the characters died. (Well, okay, not half. But a lot.) It was bittersweet. And heck, after all that crap he went through, HARRY POTTER DESERVES TO BE HAPPY.Blah blah blah. Still wracking my brain for things to say. I don't know. The thing is, the series was a bit ruined for me because I waited so long to read them; hence, I pretty much knew everything that was going to happen and was mentally/emotionally prepared for everything. So it's kind of hard to evaluate.UMMMM well. I know everyone says this but ... oh my gosh, this series has so much detail. As a writer I utterly fail at details. I'm like, "I should probably explain this more. Nah. I should give this character some kind of backstory. Nah." Whereas, J.K. Rowling has some crazy detailed history for every single one of her characters. AGGGHHH. How did she write these books in less than a hundred years? There's a purpose for everyone and everything in these books. And evidently, she had the last book planned even when she was writing the first book. A lot of series fall flat on the planning aspect; they seem like the author says to his/herself, "Meh, I don't have any other ideas so I'll just write some crappy sequel to that other thing I wrote!" But with Harry Potter, there's a reason for every book, and for everything that happens––even the smallest details. Just .... GAHHH GAHHHHHH HHHAAHGKL;KLDJ. I don't know how to express my awe. It's not fair. I now feel the need to write 100-page outlines for everything I'm writing ... which I guess is a good thing. Anyway, so, the characters. Well, as I said, there's a reason for all of them. And they all have such cool backstories. Except Harry Potter is kind of annoying. And I wish Ginny had been more interesting and that Harry's interest in her hadn't been so random. But, whatevs. I like everyone else. Ron and Hermione are an adorable couple. Voldemort is really creepy (but I love his backstory). Dobby is awesome *cries*. And OHMYGOSH I love Snape. He's so cool. I was the most sad about his death. Especially afterward when you find out his whole backstory. He and Lily had such a sweet relationship. It was so sad. AGGGH. That was the only part that almost made me cry. (Don't get me wrong, a lot of other parts made me sad, it's just that books rarely make me shed actual tears.)Recently I read this thing on Cracked.com about how it would have been cool if it turned out Neville had been the Chosen One all along. Haha. That would've been kind of awesome. But oh well. The ending was still awesome. (This has nothing to do with anything, I just wanted to mention it.)Sorry this review has pretty much no thought or structure to it whatsoever. I'm just not sure how to sum up my thoughts on all seven books. I should read them again sometime to find any cool details I might have missed––now that I know everything that happens, yada yada. Right now I just feel kinda overwhelmed by the series as a whole though, so I probably won't be rereading them for a while. But anyway, they were great.I kind of wonder whether Rowling will ever write anything else. Maybe she's the Harper Lee type and only had one good story to tell. Also I feel like if she writes about anything else, everyone will be like, "THIS IS NOT AS GOOD AS HARRY POTTER." But, oh well. I'm sure the Harry Potter legacy will live on. People will keep reading these books to their kids. J.K. Rowling is probably set for life. So, WOOHOOOO!ONE MORE THING.I solemnly swear that I am up to no good.I just love saying that. :] Heh heh.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: "'Hogwarts is threatened!' shouted McGonagall. 'Man the boundaries, protect us, do your duty to our school!'" I was so emotional throughout this whole thing. From the happiness of Harry reuniting with his friends, to the sadness of when so many dearly beloved characters died, and not to mention the anger at Dumbledore for his intricate web of lies, and the hopefulness when Dumbledore explained himself, and I realized he could be forgiven. "'Of course it is happening inside your head, Harry, but why on earth should that mean that it is not real?'" Everything came to a close perfectly. I don't really think JK Rowling could have done better. Hedwig, Mad-Eye, Ted, Fred, Lupin, and Tonks will all, forever be missed. But that was what was so brilliant about this book. It was emotional, and raw, and real. And I am forever thankful for it. "'Do not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all, those who live without love." Do I love this series with all my heart? Will I read it again and again? Will it be a part of me from now on?The answer is simple. "'Always.'" Because, "All was well." Initial reaction:"All was well."And with this book, I cried many a time. It was wonderful. It was emotional. It was everything a conclusion should be.I guess it's true what they say. The ending is the best part. So, JK Rowling presents the best part of her epic story that I will love until the end of time.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: And so ends a most enjoyable series. The search for horcruxes, a mysterious patronus, many things you never knew about Dumbledore, and a final battle that brings about the deaths of many beloved characters.At the heart of this book is love. Not the least of which is a tragic, brave love, so secret and life-long, from a person who never felt it in return. This princely love broke my heart.Much of this book with its themes of racism (pure bloods versus mud bloods) and power had me thinking of WWII, with the Death Eaters as Nazis and Voldemort as a crazed snake version of their leader (another he-who-should-not-be-named). The courage and selflessness necessary to combat this level of fear and oppression is magical, more than the magic from any wand.I've given this book five stars - is it a perfect book? No. I found the last 4 books in this series to be bloated and in desperate need of editing. Rowling repeats certain words and phrases too much for my taste. I didn't love the epilogue either, which was cheesy and felt rushed. But, the five stars are for the story, which captured me for thousands of pages.I never thought I'd read these books, so I must thank my daughter for this adventure. And no, I didn't wait for her to read this one. She's too engrossed in dragons for the time being. But when she is ready, I will be there by her side to experience it all over again.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: "Does it hurt?"The childish question had fallen from Harry's lips before he could stop it."Dying? Not at all," said Sirius. "Quicker and easier than falling asleep."   What a conclusion! As usual, I documented my experience reading this for the first time. Here is the vlog: https://youtu.be/mQes3ZwH-o4This was a bit of a slog to get through, initially, but once I got back into the rhythm of it, I felt like I was speeding through great chunks at a time, without really realising how many hours I was sitting there, locked in that position (  Ow, I ache so bad.  ). A note on problematic authors Getting back into this world, initally gave me odd and conflicting feelings, what with everything coming out about the author's hateful opinions, but I tried to distance myself from whatever hateful words the author has proclaimed, trying not to let it ruin my final trip to the wizarding world. As many fans have said, this world really does belong to us now, but with any problematic author, I do find I take it on a case by case basis, and urge you to do that as well, and although I still wanted to read the final installement, I did find myself analysing things a bit more intensely. One of the things that I found bothered me, and was, I feel, out of character for Hermione, was when she over rode Griphook, the Goblin, by basically saying her suffering was equal or greater than his... it's one of those things we've seen many times in society where those more able and privalleged instantly cry out at the "injustice", rather than listen, when others opening up their vulnerabilities by speaking of their suffering. I will leave this conversation here for now, and will continue on with my review of the finale in this series.With some of my thoughts on that being said, in a pure enjoyment level though, this was definitely the darkest books out of all 7. I didn't find it as comforting as my previous reads, because the tone (since around book 5) really does drop to a scary level. This was the time I noticed the most changes in characters, because they were pitied against decisions bigger than them, and I saw traits that I hadn't noticed before as well as those that had been there but not in this capacity, such as Ron and his, understandably, frightened doubts, Hermoine's uncertainty and admitting she doesn't always have answers and the fear of the lack of control that creates, and Harry's confusion regarding whether to trust his instinct or deem it as a cleverly constructed trap and the doubts he had on whether he was worthy of taking leadership in such a life changing quest.We didn't slack on deaths in this book, and every time one happened it was another blow that left me in disbelief. I almost had to numb myself some what just so I could get through the next few chapters without sobbing, or in a lot of cases, I just took a lot of breaks. It was  h e a v y .But ultimately, this was such a tumultuous yet gripping and emotional read. One that I am happy to have concluded. I don't usually enjoy a time jump, but because things were answered before this and it gave a beautiful ending to the story, I thoroughly enjoyed it.Although it was an emotional experience, and a journey I went into with different views due to recent news, I'm still glad that overall my final experience to this world, for the first time, was wonderful! I will miss these characters and the story they've shared.Pick it up, give it a go and enjoy! >(^_^)<Gén

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: This is the first book I have read in 2018 and I couldn’t think of a better book to do me the honour of kicking the year off with a BANG!Oh my goodness, my heart is dangling by a thread inside my rib cage, it has been brutally beaten up and has suffered SO. MUCH. PAIN. throughout these 607 pages, but it was so worth it.The final Harry Potter book, I’ve done it. I’ve finally read the Harry Potter series! I cannot believe I haven’t read this infamous series years ago. The magic, the characters, the world, the plot....absolute genius. I tip my hat to you J. K. Rowling. 🎩I don’t know how to express my all of my geelings into words because this finale has rendered me speechless.HOW am I supposed to pretend like everything is okay? I can’t just go back to facing reality, not when I know that’s it. No more Harry Potter (I don’t plan on reading the Cursed Child for the time being but that could change in the future), nothing new from these characters ever again.I will be rereading the series (or at least I hope I will) this December, and if all goes to plan, I want to reread the series every December/Winter or every other December/Winter.I have enjoyed my journey throughout reading Harry Potter, and this isn’t the end of my journey, NOPE! This is only the beginning.And I look forward to reuniting with Harry and the gang for many more years yet to come.

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text:
Yesterday I read 
Harry Potter and The Deathly Hallows
 for what seemed like the gazillionth time. I didn’t want to write a review. Again. It’s been done and it was a gushing, brimming with love and adulation write-up.Today, I just wanted to make a mini-keepsake. A little something for all my Potterhead friends. Something that encapsulated all the key moments in the books...moments that moved me...moments that made me smirk gleefully..moments that broke my heart (in a nice way, if that’s even possible). So here goes:——————————————————————————————-MOMENT #1:
‘I don’t think you’re a waste of space.’
——————————————————————————————-MOMENT #2:
“Are you planning to follow a career in Magical Law, Miss Granger?’ asked Scrimgeour. ‘No I’m not,’ retorted Hermione. ‘I’m hoping to do some good in the world!’
——————————————————————————————-MOMENT #3:
On this spot, on the night of 31 October 1981, Lily and James Potter lost their lives. Their son, Harry, remains the only wizard ever to have survived the Killing Curse. This house, invisible to Muggles, has been left in it’s ruined state as a monument to the Potters and as a reminder of the violence that tore apart their family.
——————————————————————————————-MOMENT #4:
RON:’He knew what he was doing when he gave me the Deluminator, didn’t he? He - well, he must’ve known I’d run out on you.’HARRY:’No, he must’ve known that you’d always want to come back.'
——————————————————————————————-Moment #5:
‘Dobby has no master!’ squealed the elf. ‘Dobby is a free elf, and Dobby has come to save Harry Potter and his friends!’
——————————————————————————————-Moment #6:
Here lies Dobby, a Free Elf.
——————————————————————————————-Moment #7:
‘The wand chooses the wizard,’ said Ollivander.
——————————————————————————————-Moment #8:
‘PIERTOTUM LOCOMOTOR!’And all along the corridor the statues and suits of armour jumped down from their plinths, and from the echoing crashes from the floors above and below, Harry knew that their fellows throughout the castle had done the same.‘Hogwarts is threatened! Man the boundaries, protect us, do your duty to our school!’
 ——————————————————————————————-Moment #9:
‘No,’ said Ron seriously, ’ I mean we should tell them to get out. We don’t want any more Dobbys, do we? We can’t order them to die for us -‘There was a clatter as the Basilisk fangs cascaded out of Hermione’s arms. Running at Ron, she flung them around his neck and kissed him full on the mouth.
——————————————————————————————-Moment #10:
And Percy was shaking his brother, and Ron was kneeling beside them, and Fred’s eyes stared without seeing, the ghost of his last laugh still etched upon his face.
——————————————————————————————-Moment #11:
- CHAPTER THIRTY-THREE -The Prince’s Tale
——————————————————————————————-Moment #12:
‘Have you grown to care for the boy, after all?’‘For him?’ shouted Snape. ‘Expecto Patronum!’From the tip of his wand burst the silver doe:she landed on the office floor, bounded once across the office and soared out of the window. Dumbledore watched her fly away, and as her silvery glow faded he turned back to Snape, and his eyes were full of tears.‘After all this time?’Always,’ said Snape.
——————————————————————————————-Moment #13:
‘You’ll stay with me?’‘Until the very end,’
——————————————————————————————-Moment #14:
‘Tell me one last thing,’ said Harry. ‘Is this real? Or has this been happening inside my head?’‘Ofcourse it is happening inside your head, Harry, but why on earth should that mean that it is not real?’
——————————————————————————————-Moment #15:
‘He is dead!’ Narcissa Malfoy called to the watchers.
——————————————————————————————-Moment #16:
‘I’ll join you when hell freezes over,’ said Neville.‘Dumbledore’s Army!’ he shouted.
——————————————————————————————-Moment #17:
‘NOT MY DAUGHTER, YOU BITCH!’
——————————————————————————————-Moment #18:
‘Avada Kedavra!’
‘Expelliarmus!’——————————————————————————————-Moment #19: (…and I liked the fact that it was appropriately enough, the 19th moment)
The scar had not pained Harry for nineteen years. All was well.
——————————————————————————————-

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text: “Do not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all those who live without love.”      “It is a curious thing, Harry, but perhaps those who are best suited to power are those who have never sought it. Those who, like you, have leadership thrust upon them, and take up the mantle because they must, and find to their own surprise that they wear it well.”  I’ve stated in my Half-Blood Prince review my brief history regarding the series. That I’ve technically started since 2016-2017. This is the first fantasy series I’ve read outside of school so it’s something special to me and these films are my childhood. So, I’ve anticipated this final novel for a long time, and I have to state, man it delivers. I do not know how to really begin this review and where to talk about so I will start with the beginning. The introduction is interesting I think prefer the HBP prologue, but this fits the overall mood. I would just say Dumbledore exploration was never really tapped in the movie and what a shame. The exploration of this character is truly fascinating, it’s like piecing a puzzle you see a lot of pieces and you the reader must form a proper image. You have kept in the mind the biases relaying that information. Dumbledore character has always been somewhat mystic the shrouded with mystery so having a clear understanding of his past wouldn't be right for him. So, this puzzle-like approach to his Origin was the best route Rowling could have taken. They are always a sentiment in fiction that the reader wants to know everything, but I believe it’s more the empathises should be “wants”. I think they some sort of beauty to it “wanting to know more” but in actuality knowing more would probably decrease your interest in the subject. Having enough room to properly speculate I thoroughly enjoy that and it’s up to your interpretation of events. Having to confront the truth about (view spoiler)[ Ariana secret through Aberforth eyes, that whole monologue was just very emotional. This man has one or two chapters at max and gives the man so much more depth than you really expect. Rowling conveys his pain well then you contrast that with Half-Blood Prince Dumbledore drinking the water thinking upon those events beautiful. I do love the message of the heroes we idolised aren’t necessarily all good. They are all flawed in their own ways.  (hide spoiler)] Regarding Snape (view spoiler)[ a reverse of that arc is true. His flashback chapter might be my favourite chapter in the series? I will have to think upon that but what a masterpiece. Snape as a child talking to Lily, he bit awkward he has a very good heart. The people he interacts with, slowly makes him corruptible.I quote from Dune Saga, as this relates to Snape character:“Power attracts pathological personalities. It is not that power corrupts but that it is magnetic to the corruptible.”This quote is very true to Snape character, his idols are noble, but the household of Slytherin and the people he interacts with making him corruptible. Lily and Snape's last conversation, where Lily was wearing a nightgown standing in front of the portrait of the Fat Lady, at the entrance to Gryffindor Tower. This sequence is where that aspect does show, Lily knows Snape isn’t a bad person at this point, but she knows he is dabbling in the dark arts (as he is the half-blood prince) and power is making him corruptible. The disband of their friendship was nothing to do with Mudblood situation but something more complex. Ironically Snape downfall and redemption begins with his interaction with Lily and her unfortunate passing.I will reinstate he is not a good person, but a tragic and fantastic character. I mean Dumbledore said, “You disgust me,” because he wouldn’t care about the death of James and Lily son as long Lily lives. But after some time, he really did care about Harry as a person. The Shift of Snape character can be observed through here most apparently“I have spied for you and lied for you, put myself in mortal danger for you. Everything was supposed to be to keep Lily Potter’s son safe. Now you tell me you have been raising him like a pig for slaughter —” He begins not caring about the existence of Harry and then crying for the boy. It slowly becomes he cares not just because it's Lily Son but because he cares about Harry Potter. In general, I think Snape and Dumbledore are very interesting characters to compare.  (hide spoiler)] One aspect of this novel, that hit or miss for people is the Harry centric nature of it. Much more than the other novels, it captures the sense of isolation thoroughly. If you didn’t care about Harry prior, I can see this novel being tougher for you, because this is very much his journey. One example would be chapter 16 (view spoiler)[ visiting Lily-James Potter tomb, and the former house. It's such a beautiful and reflective moment. Which hits the reader (myself) in the feels  (hide spoiler)] They a lot of Harry questioning his belief.Regarding the Plotting, well this aspect has never been Rowling strongest suit as a writer. Like it usually exists but other aspects are what makes it special I would state the same applies here. The Journey what can be a convinced somewhat simple plot is pretty heart-wrenching. The Trio to me is very special, and they all make this worth experiencing. The amount of character work we get from Hermione is just beautiful. Though one unfortunate aspect is the sole focus on Harry Potter. I like Harry as a character but as the series progresses, they just more plotlines for other people. I somewhat wished we had that Ginny, Neville or Luna POV throughout even in small doses. Because Hogwarts started becoming a character of itself, not just a location. It's somewhat my rambling thoughts but would have loved a more intimate look of its change throughout the novel would have brought something worth exploring. To make it clearer what I am saying the scope of the series becomes larger and larger. So, when the focus is tighter and tighter even though it's brilliant it's just something you wished was explored more in general.In Terms of Prose, they not much to add to the conversation. Though (view spoiler)[ The Tale of the Three Brothers  (hide spoiler)] chapter had some beautiful prose that I recognised. Its captures that fairy tale, folklore style of writing its feels a lot more deliberate than her usual style. Not sure if this is proper articulation of it but has a certain rhythmic feeling to it.Stating what I love about the novel, is almost highlighting the entire novel IMO. I have no clue of the reception of the pacing of the novel but I loved it. (view spoiler)[ Dudley saying "I don't think you're a waste of space.” Something that just felt so bloody earned. Kreacher tale was tragic and knowing more about the poor elves why he views the world in a certain matter. Remus whole arc about being a father, infiltration of the Muggle-Born Registration Commission, Luna Father chapter, Potterwatch broadcast some of the most emotional aspects of the series. Learning how the events have impacted the wizardry world, the people we care about etc. Just a powerful sequence. Especially because our trio isolation seeing those familiar figures were fantastic. Dobby funeral and the slice of life feeling of those two chapters just processing everything that transpired. Harry growth at that moment. Gringotts being such an awesome chase, already talked about it but the whole Ariana Dumbledore's situation. Seeing Neville after a year and seen how he becomes a man over that duration.Harry seeing his parents etc. Finally, Voldemort defeat.  (hide spoiler)] Some negatives and aspects I just don’t like in general. (view spoiler)[ I don’t like how the trio all become somewhat related near the end. This is probably the one aspect why I wasn’t fully on board with the Ginny-Harry coupling. Because it creates this situation where this trio that was best friends and closer than family to becoming actual family members.  (hide spoiler)] This is more of a preference aspect for me than a critique. Regarding the Hermione and Ron relationship. I do buy it but I'm just not the biggest fan of that development. This has been seeded since very early on from Book 3 you can honestly see the signs so it’s not a jarring development. But again, if this romance must be a thing I kinda hoped the Ginny-Harry Relationship wasn’t a thing because its changes that trio dynamic. The last one would be the ending. Firstly, I enjoy the ending that was provided, (view spoiler)[ Voldemort death was fitting, it made sense. Just other developments afterwards felt a tad rushed and not really touched upon. I somewhat wished they more of a mourning period and celebration, not go full-on Tolkien LOTR. I understand this is Harry story ultimately, but like we spent 7 books in this world, so many amazing arcs and yeah kind of wish Rowling would let it breathe a bit before going to the King Crossing ending. It would have been great if we had like an extra chapter or two after the official last chapter of the series. Regarding the Epilogue it’s not something I love, thematically I understood why it exists. It feels a tad abrupt. Regarding Draco, his storyline is not that great, to me, he is always a character that screams wasted potential. He had that great in the half-blood prince, but here very minor. Slytherin plotline has always been weird to me, just they so much potential that rarely tapped. I can nitpick other things but ultimately the elements I said above and here are what matters to me.  (hide spoiler)] In Conclusion, this is an incredible novel to an amazing series. Some fantastic characters, incredible atmosphere, sparking the imagination of million so forth. Rowling had one hell of time completing this juggernaut of a series. Especially with all the intense pressure, this was the biggest movie of its release and I doubt another book release will have this much attention. I can have my gripes, nit-picks etc. But I truly love this series. It’s the first fantasy series I read outside of school during 2016-2017. Only completing it this year, after reading many more series. It’s a movies series I grew up with though not the books but thank God I took the plunge and read it. In terms of enjoyment this series always going to be like a 10 but I don’t rate books purely upon enjoyment. Anyways saying goodbye to this world is like a goodbye to a friend. Of course, I can always reread this series, but that first time experience is something special. Though nothing lasts forever so goodbye and thankful for this experience.  8.5 or 9/10 not sure 😊

book_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
text:
BLOG REVIEW:https://passthefeels.wordpress.com/20...Well, I had written half of this review and it just decided to delete itself, so heres take 2 I guess. It was much more poetic the first time... *fumes*I usually don't know where to start with reviews, however this time I feel both like I'll never be able to start, as much as I feel like I'll never be able to stop.I guess I'll just start by simply saying:
I love Harry Potter.
I would, without a doubt, not be the person I am today without it.I grew up with the films, and read the books later on in life, which I do not regret, as I believe it allowed me to have full understanding and appreciation for the novels, at this age.Anyway, this is not a shrine, it's a review, sooo, here we go.This book was incredible. More so than I ever imagined. I loved it, and it's going straight to the favourites of all time shelf.I don't even really know exactly what to say, all I know is it was amazing from start to finish, but I'll try to form coherent sentences through my shock that I've actually finished reading these now...Looking back on the novel whilst trying to write this review has made me realise how every chapter is like a mini book. Each named appropriately to it's contents, which have taken up little places in my mind, as if they've been filed into categories.From the very beginning, when Harry finally departed from the Dursleys, my heart swelled. Rowling could not have written that scene any better. I just feel it was done perfectly to solidify the way in which they and Harry felt about each other, truly, in the end.I found the entire quest for the horcruxes to be so enthralling. The three friends and their voyage to take down Voldemort, as well as help each other. Especially Hermione and Harry's time in Godric's Hollow, that swelled my heart.The Tale of the Three Brothers. The Deathly Hallows! I have always been fascinated with this, and have never quite fully understood them simply through the film, but reading about it just gave me this whole new insight into the stories and history behind this brilliant idea Rowling had. I absolutely loved this huge aspect of the novel.Severus! The worldly conflict, the never ending debate on whether or not he was a good man... I have finally made up my mind on whether I love him or hate him, and have decided that I love him. Yep. One of the other millions of favourite moments throughout this book has to be the Pensieve scene, surrounding Snapes memories. Harry's journey through Snapes mind was so incredibly interesting, and certainly both made and broke my heart. To finally understand why Snape was the way he was, ahh, just, yes.The Battle of Hogwarts. Do I really need to say more? Wow. The ending, the whole last section was just brilliant. I think it may even be my favourite last part of a book ever. It was executed so well, and tied everything together so well. Once again, the appreciation for Fred and Georges humour, even in times of sorrow, was one of the many highlights of this entire series. As well as Harry, Hermione and Ron's friendship. Their friendship, I believe, is one of the most, if not the most, important aspects of the entire series. I am obsessed with them, in-fact all of the relationships Rowling manages to create are so intricate, and really tug on the heart strings.We got to see the continued relationship between Harry and Dumbledore, which was so nice. I even found myself warming to Kreacher! Oh how unexpected, but lovely.19 years later...Ahhh, I could not deal with this part! It was everything. I feel so lucky to have finally been able to read it. Also, to now be able to continue on with The Cursed Child.Anyway, this is definitely the longest review I have ever done, and I think it's time to stop.If you made it this far, thank you for reading, and I hope (I'm sure) you loved this book as much as I did (or are excited to read it).I'm going to go wipe my tears, watch the Deathly Hallows movies, and fantasise about starting the whole series again... I might just do that. Bye!Order of favourite to least favourite HP book:1. Deathly Hallows2. Half Blood Prince3. Order of the Phoenix4. Philosophers Stone5. Prisoner of Azkaban6. Goblet of Fire7. Chamber of Secrets
